text: 11/26/16. Bottle my parents brought down. Thanks! Amber pour with a nice khaki head, good lacing. Nice smoke aroma, not too much, chewy, caramel. Good flavor, nice smoke balance, campfire, caramel, malty, biscuit. Tasty!

12floz bottle without freshness dating purchased about six months ago from consumption date 03.23.2017. Note a label change from Unplugged to a thumbprint design. Paid $3 for a single. Poured vigorously into a normal sized nonic glass. Appears dark brown with a pillowy light-tan head. Nose invites me to a feast of a drinking experience. Aromatics are of woodsy smoke, such as a campfire. Some smoked meat is in there as well. This transcends to robustly balanced palate hickory and a touch of cocoa. Creamy upon first taste, then it following through with smokey and mildly roasted. I wonder if this would go with BBQ. Yet, it tastes like a BBQ. So maybe not enough to contrast. Ok, I got it. Steak and taters would seem to be appropriate. Its been a while since I last had a really good smoked porter. This ranks up there with Alaskan as a contemporary.
Thanks Dannys Mom! New Glarus is pretty rocking it again. Chocolate base creamy body with nice mild smokiness. All around pleasant.

Bottle thanks to Jimmy! Pours opaque chestnut, very large creamy tan head, dissipates slowly, really nice lacing. Aroma is nicely smoky, hardwood fire, roasted malt, cocoa. Flavor is medium smoke, light sweet, light bitter, roasty while avoiding being meaty. Medium body, creamy mouthfeel. Good stuff.

Got in a trade with the The-Adjunct-Hippie. 12 ounce bottle into pint glass, best before 12/4/2016. Pours clear nearly opaque dark brown color with a 1-2 finger dense tan head with good retention, that reduces to a small cap that linger. Light spotty soapy lacing clings down the glass, with a moderate amount of streaming carbonation retaining the cap. Aromas of big peat smoke, wood, chocolate, cocoa, coffee, toasted dark bread, and herbal; with lighter notes of caramel, charcoal, fruit, leather, pepper, and roast/smokey earthiness. Nice and pleasant aromas with good balance and complexity of roast/bready/smoked malt and light-moderate earthy hop notes; with solid strength. A bit too fruity/peaty in the nose, but not overwhelming. Taste of big peat smoke, wood, chocolate, cocoa, coffee, toasted dark bread, and herbal; with lighter notes of caramel, charcoal, fruit, leather, pepper, and roast/smokey earthiness. Light-moderate herbal/spicy hop and roast/char bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of peat smoke, wood, chocolate, cocoa, coffee, toasted dark bread, herbal, light pepper, and roast/smokey earthiness on the finish for a good bit. Great complexity, robustness, and balance of roast/bready/smoked malt and light-moderate earthy hop flavors; with a great roast/hop bitter/sweet balance, and zero cloying flavors after the finish. Light dryness from roast/hop bitterness, lightly increasing through the glass. Medium carbonation and body; with a very smooth, moderately creamy/bready, and fairly sticky/chalky balanced mouthfeel that is great. Zero warming alcohol as expected of 6.1%. Overall this is a very nice smoked American porter style. All around nice complexity, robustness, and balance of roast/bready/smoked malt and light-moderate earthy hop flavors; very smooth and easy to drink. Other than the aromas being a bit off; this was spot on for an American porter in every way. A very enjoyable offering.

Its pretty crazy that Wisconsins best brewery (OK, top 3 at worst) doesnt have a standard porter among its dozens of beers. Its even crazier that the smokiness is so well balanced, considering that most smoked beers Ive tried seem like pyromaniacs projects gone wild. Smoke on the Porter has a smoky sweetness throughout the aroma and taste. It makes me wish Dan Carey would make a few more porters and maybe just a plain one (which Im certain would be anything but).
Super good smoked beer. Just exactly the right amount of smoke married perfectly to a classic porter. Really nice.

Multiple bottles over the past few weeks
Pours very dark brown almost black with a nice small tight lacking head and sparse lacing. Nice looking brew for sure. Nose is smokey wood lots of dark chocolate and lite char. Flavors are lite smoke up front lite metallic minerals big dark chocolate lite char. Finish is lovely lite smoke and very dry. Fantastic brew here. I think I like this more than Alaskan smoked porter. Body is full yet fairly crisp for the style and abv. Another home run from NG.

Smoke on the Porter? Hmm, wonder what style New Glarus has brewed here... New Glarus has absolutely upped the ante for smokiness with this ale. Brown color. Aroma is intensely meaty. Its the mouth-watering salty smell of cured, smoked bacon and country ham. Just a bit of tobacco in there, too. My only regret about drinking this beer is that I didnt enjoy it with some of Wisconsins Bavarian-style sausages. After all, the state isnt just known for its cheese.

Bottle.

A- Smoke, savory.

A- Dark brown color, dark liquid, tan head.

T- Smoke, umami, meaty.

P- Medium body, average texture, average carbonation, smoky finish.

O- Definitely a ton of smokiness. Wish it had a tad more porter characteristics but still tasty. A bit thin too.

12oz bottle pours a dark brown with amber highlights and a large khaki head. Aroma of smoked malt and molasses. Taste begins with sweet chocolate and molasses with smoked ashy malt hitting earthy bitter hops. Nice!
Bottle shared by jcos. Dark brown pour with a thin light brown head and light lace. Nice smokey aroma and flavor. Dry roast. Really tasty smoke beer.

Deep dark pour with a little red on the edges underneath a single finger tan colored head. Lace present. Aroma of smoke and a hint of fruity yeast. Slightly sweet, like a campfire smoke. Medium bodied. Taste is full of sweet campfire smoke. Reminds me of what burned wood smells like after a fire Taste also has some fruity esters and yeast notes. Nice beer.

Tasted from bottle. Pours black with tan head. Aroma is big time bacon and smoked meats. Taste is mildly bitter with some smoky sweetness. Campfire smokey flavor is not overpowering. Flavors of cured meats, coffee, faint dark chocolate. Just a little more thin than Iike but very well done. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Aroma is dark malts and definitely fruit growing wood/smoke. The flavor is smoke/oak/mild fruit wood, fruit and an acidic/tart/heat in the finish.

Bottle poured dark cola brown with a tan head and dissipating lacing. Aromas of chocolate, smoked malt, vanilla, and lactose. Flavor is mild dark chocolate bitter with a slightly sweet creamy finish. Tasty.
Bottle. Smoked meat, chocolate malt, and hay aroma. Black with large tan head. Mildly sweet coffee/chocolate, smoked ham, and mildly bitter wood/herbal hay flavor. Nice body and balance. Delicious.

Out of the bottle, poured dark black with a large tan head. I got notes of bonfire smoke, smoked bacon, dark chocolate, espresso. Repeats of these roasted malt notes on the palate, along with black liquorice, black tea and tobacco/cigar. Lingering malt bitterness/ashiness on the palate. Did not perceive hops or esters. Overall a pleasant smoked porter with a long finish that would do well with salty cheese, or charred/smoked proteins (perhaps a chargrilled burger topped with bacon and aged cheddar!).
From Bushel and Peck. Wonderful stuff, both robust and restorative. Some smoke but not like drinking a campfire. Smooth and slick mouth feel. Serving: Bottle
12oz bottle shared. Dark black pour. Aroma is nice smoke, some bandaid. Taste is money, beef jerky. This is pretty good.
Bottle shared by Tom - thanks! Rich dense dark pour with a soapy head. Some band aid on aroma - too bad. Taste doesnt suffer - mild beer jerkey. Solid.
12 oz 2016 thumbprint. Black thin khaki head. Aroma is smoke. Flavor is smoked malt. Slight chocolate. Band aid flavor on the finish.

12 ounce bottle from Badger Spirits in Janesville, WI (July 2016), served at cellar temperature in a New Glarus Glass. Not-quite-opaque black body topped by a very creamy taupe head, slowly diminishing...light to moderate smokiness in the nose, mostly typical porter dark roasted malts; I know porters are pretty popular to hit with the smoker, but this is not the first time Ive thought that the Germans have had it right all along - smoking lagers gives you a stronger smoky intensity just about every time; if youre using smoked malt in something that already has a lot of roastiness and sometimes comes off as smoky, whats the point? anyway its a nice nose, but its got nothing on Schlenkerla thats for sure...on the tongue, its a bit more distinctive I think, with a lovely velvety semi-sweet initial flavor, lots of sweet caramelized malts here, giving way slowly but implacably to an almost overwhelming finishing bitterness and burnt character that verges on harshness...the full body and soft mouthfeel and low-to-moderate carbonation are well-judged, and this ends up a pretty impressive experience after all, even if its not going to displace any of my favorite smoked lagers anytime soon...

Bottle:
Black with a small, dark tan head.
Smoke, chocolate, tobacco scent.
Sweet, smoky chocolate malt, roast...the applewood comes through nicely....
A little sweet and on the light side, but still, a pretty stellar smoked offering.

Shared 12 oz. bottle poured to snifters showing a black/brown hue, a modest layer of tan head foam, and dots & dashes of lacing. The nose was roasted, mocha notes, smoke & char, with a hint that may have been meaty, but came off to me as fabric Band-Aid. Medium bodied, with moderate carbonation, the taste was as the aroma, less the tape, but not the presentable smoke & char. Mellow roasted & earthy bitterness, without a typical tannic astringency. A decent Smoked brew.
RBSG 2016 shared at the Grand Tasting after-party in the hotel lobby. Bottle. Dark amber brown. Moderate meaty smoke, brown bread crusts, excellent balance.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Smoked flavours, dark, toasted malts, coffee. Hazy, dark brown, small, creamy, off-white head. Light bitter. More toasted, dark malts, cacao, coffee, soft carbonation. Very nice Smoked, well-balanced. Keg at The Old Fashioned, Madison, WI.

[Bottle] Pours dark brown with a very small head. Aroma is rounded smokiness and subtle anise. Restrained and simple, but nice. Taste is balanced between smoked barley, light hops, and a faint sweetness that I cant quite peg. Medium-thin, but smooth and has a long finish. Overall, smoked beers can get overpowering pretty quickly, and arent always my favorite. However, this one has great balance and Is probably one of the best smoked beers Ive ever had.

Purchased at Woodman's in Kenosha, WI; enjoyed at a vacation home for a family reunion in Lake Delavan, WI. Appearance is pitch black with a rich dark tan head. Aroma of smoked malt and chocolate, smells pretty good. Taste is very good, reminds me of Schlenkerla, rich in smoke and not heavy, light chocolate profile. I like this very much.

Pours a dark, cola-black, with minimal head. Aroma is dominated by smoke, but there are roasted grains apparent as well. Flavor also dominated by smoke, with a good amount of coffee, chocolate, some leather, roasted grain, etc. Pretty good and would probably go well with meat and cheese.
355ml bottle. An old one revived. This is the new version obviously. IT is rich and meaty a bit funky like say a schlenkerla but with a big chocoalte note as well. Good stuff.

12 oz. bottle purchased at the brewery on 7-19-16. Bottle doesnt say Unplugged, just Smoke on the Porter. The UPC barcode was correct, so Im assuming this is the correct beer. Poured black, tan head. Aroma was smoky, dark roast coffee, roasted malts. Taste was sweeter, dry, bitter chocolates, roasted malts. Nice.

12oz bottle. Thumbprint 2016 version. Deep brown-black body. Thin, steady beige head. Creamy, luscious, deep malt tones. Pleasant thick smoky tones, sweet bready brown chocolate malts. Easy drinking, though approaching full bodied. Fresh, delicious, really well done.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with small tan head that diminishes to nothing. The aroma is strong smoke, roast, chocolate. Medium mouth, similar flavors to nose, light smoke, sugary malt, easy to drink, really good.

12 oz. bottle shared by shigadeyo- thanks, Craig! He said it was a 2007 vintage. It pours a hazy, deep cola brown with a few bubbles on the surface and some wispy film. It has an initial smoky and rubbery character, with dark chocolate, burnt sugar, earth, and some ashy notes in the back. Light-bodied, with low carbonation and a flat, smoky, smooth mouthfeel. Certainly has thinned over the years and isnt as sharp as it once wouldve been, but its not bad.

12oz bottle, thanks to shigadeyo for sharing. 2007 bottle, apparently. Mostly clear brown color. Very little off-white head. Smoke, a bit of rubber in the nose. Wow, actually a nice bit of dark chocolate in the flavor, nice mild dark fruit, good bigger-porter type flavor. Moderate sweet taste, moderate bitter. Very light carbonation, but honestly I dont mind it at all. Good bit of chewiness to the texture, medium to bigger body. Tasty stuff. Nice big milk chocolate on the finish.
Bottle in Vail. Thanks to adnielsen for sharing. Pours an deep brown color with white head. Smoke, wood, roasty, slight milk aromas. Nice smoke flavor.
Refrigerated 12 oz. brown bottle poured into a sample glass. Pours dark brown with off-white head. Taste is smoke, roasty, with some hops. Pretty good.
Bottle. Pours a dark brown with no head. Aroma is smoky and roasty. Lots of smoke coming through. Warming on the throat.

Bottle from - shrug? - Breeze Thru is the guess, cellared since Feb 11 according to my notes. Pours a quite dark black/brown with some reddish tints and an offbrown head leaving some drippy lacing. Aroma has smoke, and also chocolate and licorice and roasted malt. Taste is of salty meat smoke, sweet chocolate and roasted malts. Nicely balanced between the "smoke" component and the "porter" component. My memory of this fresh two years ago was more smoke-y and not as much porter-y, but that is anecdotal. This is quite yummy.  Medium to full bodied. Could be more chocolate/roasty rich, in my opinion, but that angle perhaps would kill the smoke. Finishes slightly bittersweet, and a touch smokey. This is a nice one. Hope Dan brings it back at some point.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2016 Bottle.  Finally.  Deep brown with a hint of red.  Thin tan head.  Still has a good nose of salty smoke and bacon.  Some background elements of cocoa roasted malt and faint dark fruit.  Flavor is even roasted malt/cocoa powder, mild smoke, charcoal, a tinge of plastic at the end.  Mostly residual roasted malt/charcoal.  Thinner than anticipated.  This has withstood some age.  Quality in, quality out. Re-rate: 2016 version.  Light ashy charcoal and light roast cocoa character. +1

Big thanks to CaptainCougar for this beer.  Served in a mini snifter.  Pours a dark brown color with a good head.  The nose has a moderate amount of smoke alongside some roast and a very light fruit component.  Flavor is smokey and roasty.  Nice and integrated.  Medium body with good carbonation and a lingering smokiness.  Not surprisingly, a German take on a beer that was done well by New Glarus.
Clear brown with a small head. Lactic chocolate with hints of toffee and caramel. Marshmallow and butterscotch in the finish. Not bad at all.

355mL thanks to CaptainCougar. Pours a clear a very deep ruby with rich beige foam. Rich smoky nose. Sausage, steak, peat, fat. Thicker lacing. Taste is lighter, tangy, savory smoke, lemon tea, mild cocoa. Palate is light and aerated. Lemon acid. Refreshing. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Ive been saving this for some time, and wow, it was delicious. Pours a rich dark brown with a reasonably generous head. Delicious smoke in the aroma, with notes of chocolate and just a hint of salami. Smooth and porter-thin body, with a wonderful smoke resonance. It didnt really improve as it warmed, though, interestingly. Easy drinking. Excellent beer, all around. Bottle.
Pours a deep black with thin off white head. aroma of smoke and chocolate. flavor is spot on for this style. Perfect.

Courtesy of northernbrews
Bottle:  The aroma consists of smoked meat and a touch of chocolate.  It pours a dark brown with a small beige head.  The flavor starts with chocolate and caramel.  The finish has moderate smoke and faint roast.  Light-medium bodied with mild carbonation.

Bottle @ home, courtesy of Brigadier (I think?). Black appearance with a weak brown head that doesnt last more than a manner of seconds. Sweet, roasty charred wood, dark malty nose with a hint of light fruits. Well carbonated. Mildly sweet fruity, moderately smoky, charred, dark malty flavor. Lightly smoky, lightly fruity, dark malty aftertaste. Solid beer but nothing super special. That being said, if this was offered year-round around here, I would buy it fairly often.
black with beige head. aroma of heavy, rich smoke, chocolate, beef jerky...heavily roasted..flavor of smoked meat, roastiness...the smoke is drowning out all other possible nuances and subtleties...

A- Body is a dark brown nearly black hue. Pours with a foamy 1-2 finger dark tan head-which eventually fades to a thin collar and leaves little lacing in the glass.

S- Decent amount of smoke, smoked meat, a hint of roasted malt and vanilla underneath.

T- The taste is a lot more reserved and less in your face than the nose. The initial flavors are good, classic porter flavors. Slightly sweet overall0 Vanilla, chocolate, a hint of roasted malt. The finish adds a touch of smoked meat to everything else thats already going on and balances everything out perfectly.

M-Medium carbonation and a nice smooth creamy mouthfeel.

D- This is a very good beer overall. Great mouthfeel-good smoke character over a porter. Very well balanced and easy to drink-too bad this is limited. Sweet and smokey.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-21-2011 02:50:14

Traded 12oz bottle. Pours ultra dark brown with a thin khaki head. The aroma starts about a foot from the glass. Really big sweeter malt and chocolate notes from the porter influence but then you pick up some faint BBQ smoke too. The mouthfeel is silky smooth. The best description I can give is a "smoked porter"...no joke. Great porter flavor and then the smoke finishes things out nicely. Long, chocolatey finish.

Bottle shared by badnewsbeers. Deep opaque brown body with reddish highlights, medium tight tan head. Smoky nose, leathery, with bacon notes. Meaty, smoky body, partially concealing the coffee, cereal, and burnt sugars of the base porter. Somewhat woody.
Bottle. Pours dark brown, almost black. Nose of intense smoke, BBQ pork, roasted chocolate malts and vanilla. Taste is creamy chocolate malts, grain, toffee, smoke and barbecue. Medium body.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown brown color wih a slight tan head. The aroma is smoky but not extremely so, no more like only a small campfire as opposed to the full on smoke of some other beers. Laces on the glass pretty well. Slightly sweet tasting up front with a mild smokiness that lingers. Medium/light mouthfeel. In the world of smoke beers this one is on the light side but very easy drinking. This would be the ideal beer to introduce people to smokes.
Bottled. A deep red beer with a thin beige head. The aroma has notes of malt and caramel. The flavor is sweet with notes of malt, leading to a dry roasted finish. Where is the smoke?

Tuesday Tasting sample thanks to grownfool.  Dark dark brown, tan head.  Aroma is ashy, woody, smoke, caramel and chocolate.  Taste is more chocolate, woody, smoky, ash.  This one might have thinned out slightly, but is holding up well.

A: snifter. pours an abyss-like color, impenetrable to light. nice light khaki color head. medium retention with mild lacing.

S: huge roasted malt aroma. some chocolate, coffee, with a hint of smoke. some sweet/tart cherries in the back.

T: smoked sexual chocolate. some serious ham flavors. nice roasted malts, great chocolate notes.

M: smooth, creamy. perfect carbonation level. medium-bodied.

D: could drink a sixer easliy for breakfast with some canadian bacon.

Bottle shared by Sean, thanks! Poured a clear reddish brown with a gray head that dissipated immediately to the edges. Aroma was full of a sweet smokey note with strong underlying sweet grains. Flavor was full of sweet grains as well but the smoke note was much more reserved and grew a bit towards the finish.

Sampled on 7/31/10. This smoked porter pours an eclipse black color from a 12oz bottle. Small to medium sized beige foamy head. The aroma is chocolate, coffee, dark fruit and some smoke. A medium bodied smoked porter. The malts are roasty and chocolate, touch of coffee and a nice mellow smokiness in the background. The hops are herbal. The smoke is evident, but mostly in the background. A nice smoky porter with an excellent flavor balance. Nice balance. Good carbonation. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly bitter.

12oz bottle pours a watery, deeply transparent brown with a little cloudy white head.  Nose is nice, lightly smokey, bacon, light wood.  Flavor is malty, brown sugar, smoke, sweet.  Finish is medium bodied and sweet and smokey.

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of malt, chocolate, and a hint of smoke.  
Poured very dark brown/ruby in color with a small to medium-sized, creamy, dense, rocky, tan head that lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Not sparkling.  Full of tiny, small, medium, and large-sized particles throughout.  Excellent lacing  Flavor is lightly sweet and lightly bitter.  Tastes of smoke, roasted malt, light chocolate, light Bamburg wood, and a hint of coffee.  Medium body.  Slick, creamy texture.  Soft carbonation.  Roasted malt, light chocolate, slight smoke, and a hint of Bamburg wood in the finish.

In the bottle at Bill Bs 2010 summer beer tasting party. Pours near black with a dark beige head. Huge campfire ham aroma. Thin in body and surprisingly low smoke to the taste considering the huge smoke aroma. Great chocolate finish. A fantastic beer.

Pours a nearly opaque brown w/ a small but dense light brown head.  Aroma fills of chocolate and roasted malts w/ a hint of chard wood that come through almost salty.  Flavor is sweet milk chocolate but well balanced by light smoke and fruits along w/ a dry piney hop in the finish.  The palate is a little to thin for my tastes, but acceptable.  A very nice beer to drink.

Appearance: An attractive chocolate brown with a creamy beige 1 finger crown that shows some retention and loads of lace.

Smell and Taste: A hypnotic medley of chocolate, roast malt, hazelnut, and coffee. I bet the nose and taste were even more potent when this one off was first released.

Mouthfeel: Very creamy medium bodied brew that is a bit chewy.

Drinkability: Btw the flavor and the mouthfeel I could drink this one all day and night.

Another Home Run From New Glarus!

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-13-2009
thanks to Hophead22 for the tasting.From a 12oz bottle,black in color,thin white head,Smells and taste like bacon.
12oz bottle. Rating #330. Dark brown color. Dark fruits and light smoke. Light flavor a little roast, very nice. (1235)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: Robust earthy smoky aroma like a creamy gouda. dark chocolate body, sticky tan head. smoky charcoal, chewy maple. even a touch of syrup sweetness in the finish.

Thanks to angrypirate06 for sharing this beer.

The beer pours black with a tan head. The aroma is strong smoke and roasted malt. The flavor is a meaty BBQ smoke with some roasted malt. The smoke is the predominant flavor but it doesnt overpower. Medium, slightly creamy mouthfeel and low carbonation.
Bottle courtesy of angrypirate06. Dark brown color. Aroma of deep beef jerky. Smoked ham and fair malts. Taste is easy smoke with slight bacon grease. Slight smoke finish. Turkey beef jerky.  Cool.
Bottle from angrypirate06.  Pour is brown.  Aroma is meaty chocolate and vanilla.  Flavor is weaker, but still pretty meaty.  Coffee on the finish.

12oz bottle thanks to angrypirate06.  Poured a clear, deep dark brown body with mahogany highlights.  Aromas of freshly started mesquite-smoked BBQ along with some light sweetness.  Flavor is "choco-smoke", coffee and a light bitter finish.  Thin to medium body.  Enjoyable smokey/coffee long finish.

(12oz bottle thanks to angrypirate06) Pours medium opaque brown. Nose of milk chocolate, wood, bbq. Taste of wood, bbq, smoke, more wood, light alcohol, creamy with a medium body thats creamy. This is one of the best smoked beers Ive had!

Bottle shared by Rogueone at my Super Awesome Ridiculous Stout Tasting on 1/23/10. Clear dark brown pour with a medium tan head. Aroma of firewood, chocolate and sweet and roasted malts. Malty flavor with chocolate and firewood before a roasty finish. Got a little hammy when it hit room temperature, but at serving temp the smoke wasnt too much.

Sampled at the Hopsnobbery Collective Stout tasting on 01/23/10. The beer pours a deep dark brown color with a medium beige head that lasts awhile. Stringy lacing on the glass. Aroma of smoked malts and cocoa. Medium, smooth body with a smoked character that is not over the top. Flavors of roasted malt, chocolate and meat as well. The finish is smoked bacon and leaves a malty aftertaste. Well done overall.

Bottle acquired via trade with glouglouburp -- thanks!!  Pours a dark plum color with a fair tan head.  Smells of smoked malt and hops.  Tastes of both with added notes of lactose, wood, and raisins.   My kind of beer, for sure.

Bottle.  Poured a dark, completely opaque brown with a tall light brown head.  Nose is roasted chocolate malts with some smokey bacon notes.  Medium body with very soft carbonation.  Flavor is roasted and malty with notes of smoke, vanilla, and coffee.  Finishes smokey.

From notes. Black/brown, small off white head. Subtle multi-wood smoked malts on top of a subtle porter. Too mild all around. Medium body, balanced. Easy drinking session brew, expected a little more impact from an unplugged.

12oz bottle thanks to bret27, I think.   Dark ruby red with a small beige head.   Big smokey bacon aroma with some roasted malt as well, but just a rush of smoke.   Beautiful if simple.   The flavor is relatively dry with lots of smoke over some chocolatey roasted malt flavors.   Total smoke bomb.   Medium-light body with medium carbonation.   Very nicely drinkable maltiness, while being a refreshing whack in the face with smoked malts.   This is what I want in a smoked porter, not any of that "subtle" rubbish that leaves me wondering why they even bothered.

12oz bottle shared at a tasting.  Pours very dark brown with a small off-white head that fades to a film.  Awesome smoky and roasty aroma, with hints of meat in there.  Flavor is also great and smoky with roasted malt, smoked meat, toffee, and dark chocolate.  Really interesting and good beer.  Medium bodied with a smooth mouthfeel and lasting smokiness.

Dont remember who brought this but thanks! Pours dark brown with a light tan lacy head. Aroma is bacony with chocolate, ash, and smoke. Really the smokiest "smoked porter" Ive had. Flavor is smoked meat with some roasty bitterness and dark chocolate. Slightly acidic. Soft carbonation, medium body.

Bottle: &nbsp Fairly black, certainly darker than your average Porter, large batter like head, light beige, sticky lacing. &nbsp Immediate smoke on first whif, charred wood, heavy roasted malts, with a very very slight smoked 

meat aspect. &nbsp A little lighter on the tongue, certainly heavily roasted malts, charred wood, campfire, some ash, but also getting a bit of lactose sweetness and even some apple skin. &nbsp Fairly smooth, moreso than expected. &nbsp 

Has a somewhat creamy finish. &nbsp Lingering maltiness, soft roastiness, with a bit of campfire. &nbsp This was really pleasant, not as heavy as the Alaskan Smoked Porter which I must say is a welcomed change. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel 

are moderate to full. &nbsp Oh yeah, definitely smooth. &nbsp Wow, this one is pretty damn tasty. &nbsp Is it possible for Dan to make a bad beer? &nbsp I wish we had someone with his brewing skills out there... fantastic lagers, fruit 

beers, wheats, and now porters. &nbsp So clean too... with lingering cocoa and chocolate. &nbsp Holy piss is this nice! &nbsp Not heavy, and very well balanced. &nbsp Good shit! &nbsp Major thanks to Skyview for sending this 

wonderful creation! &nbsp Solid

Bottle from allendod. Thanks for this rarity! Pours very dark brown with a 3-finger tan head. Aroma is smoky. Medium minus body with mildly creamy carbonation. Flavor is smoky, darkly roasted malt. Feel turns lightly greasy. The flavor is not bacon, but sure brings it to mind. Finish is simply smooth. Nice.

bottle, pours dark brown with a tall frothy brown head.  Nice worchetshire sauce and steak with smoked malt aroma.  Wow, great chocolate malt and smoked malt flavors.  Very complex with a nice lingering smoke steak finish.  This is an awesome smoked brew.

From Cletus via trade.  Poured cola like into a shaker glass.  The head was off-white and one-finger tall.  Spotty lacing.  The aroma was light smoke and thin chocolate with a touch of sour fruit.  The flavor is roasted malts, chocolate and some smoke.  A tad sour towards the finish.  Body is on the thin side.  More porter than smoked in my mind.  OK.

Another want list beer that bbb63 hand delivered for nothing in return.  Thanks again, Mike!  Pours a Dark brown with a small tan head.  aroma of smoked meats, dust, chocolate.  Flavor is smoke, earth,  and a subtle bitter sweet chocolate.   Soft, slightly sticky mouthfeel.   The smokiness is much more mellow compared to the Calumet grand chef, which is the last smoked I had.  Very nice and interesting beer.  Dont pass up the chance to try it!  Thanks again, MIke!  I owe you ten or so!
Bottle shared with Rudolf. Deep dark pour. Smokey mesquite like aroma. Roasted Malts, full mouthfeel. Smokey up front, then mellow a tad. Creamy & roasty. Very good

Bottle, thanks secretsanta!  Deep mahogany, almost black.  Tan head.  Nose is smokey iodine, somked fish, roasty malt, dusty cocoa.  Flavor is smoke, roasty sweet malt, a bit of molasses & dark honey.  More of that sweetness comes out in the finish w. really nice roasty malts.  Bittersweet smokey awesome.

Bottle thanks to Glouglouburp!Dark brown, moderate beige head gone quickly. Nose has smoke and leaves, also some rich porter malt and milk chocolate. Flavor is almost all porter, only hints of smoke lingering in the slightly sticky finish. Decent beer, just not enough smoke or complex porter.

Deep brown beer.  Nose is pretty nice.  Lots of rich smoky aroma with a heavy beechwood contribution.  The malts are lightly chewy with a light earthy cocoa flavour through the middle.  A touch of saltiness on the back that gives it a briny complexity.  Moderate palate and a lingering earthy bitterness that complements the smoke nicely.  Pretty delicious really.

12oz bottle... Its a shame I dont remember from whom!  Either Mreusch, I think!  I used to absolutely hate smoked beers... Until I really tried them... Now I love, and brew them!  Anyway....  Dark, very dark w/ a lasting light beige head.  Really, apple smoked bacon comes to mind!  Very strong and dominant, but to me, very appealing! Other malt aroma is toasty.  Flavor is malty, toasty, and bacon flavored smoke with a bit of chocolate and roasty malt.  Dry finish with smoked malt and roasty aftertaste.  M/F is very light medium bodied, dry and lighter CO2.  Overall, a very outstanding beer!  I wish I had more!  Very clean smoke aroma/flavor, nice porter qualities, and in general, a great beer!
Dark pour with a nice beige head. Aroma of smoke but not overpowering. Flavor of smoke, cocoa, and malt. A really nice beer.

Big thanks to Miketd for passing this onto me via Craig, cheers Mike, consumed 20-08-09   Pours dark brown with a large cushion of light beige foam. The aroma is smokey but its quite subtle and in no way overpowering also there is a touch of liquorice on the nose. Taste is smoky, light sweetness slight tang of sourness but quite lovely. Feels wonderful in the mouth like an Aero chocolate bar melting on the tongue with all those tiny bubbles dispersing. Its smooth, there is some chocolate, its just lovely stuff.  A8 A4 F8 P5 Ov14  4.1

Bottle: Deep brown pour with a thick tan head. Nice smoky presence in the aroma- some earthy wood and ham with a cocoa note as well. Nice creamy velvetty feel. The flavor is quite smoky as well- not very smoky but it does posses some peat notes, cocoa malt suggestions and toasted dark crystal malts. Nice malt character- pretty solid.

Bottle from buckybeer - Thanks! - Pours a dk dk brown with a large but fleeting creme colored head...aroma is cocoa and smoke, dirty malt and cola...just incredible in the mouth, creamy with a wonderfully light carbonation...cocoa, charred wood bitterness, root beer and some light fruit...finish is dry and lingering...nicely done!

12 oz bottle thanks to Ughsmash. Pours a very dark brown-black with thin, but persistent, tan head. The aroma is coffee, smoked beef, a little bit of chocolate, some licorice, some prune, and a distant cigar tobacco note. The flavor isnt quite as smoky as the aroma made me expect; it starts off with a nice roasty note with a little bit of a tart berry note. The smoke then comes in and smooths everything out with a sort of rich meatiness. Chocolate, prune, and vanilla come into play, also. The finish is chocolate, molasses, and jerky. This is a very tasty beer... I could drink a lot of it.

Dark chocolatey brown pour, thin head. Smells of paint, smoke, meats, hops, and alcohol. Tastes of sweet malts, smoky, meaty, woody finish. Vanilla. Thin and clear, kind of overwhelming to drink an entire glass, but good for a few sips.
Smells like smoked meat, alcohol, burnt wood. Thin mouthfeel.  Smoke flavor on the back of my palate, pretty subdued. Cocoa notes. Nicely balanced flavor profile, nice work NG. Thanks again lopes.

Thanks Hopscotch! Aroma is at first a bit underdeveloped, but as the beer breathes and warms, a nice smoked character comes through. The smoked aroma bears some hints of hickory wood and a slight peat character. Coffee and roasted malt round out the flavor. The aroma has a more smokey presence from start to finish and is the most dominate. Also present are hints of coffee, dark chocolate, nut, charcoal, and meat. Overall not too bad for a smoked beer.

Thanks Noncaloric!

Appearance:  Pours a midnight brown with a 1/4 inch stripe of tan head.

Aroma:  Smoked meat, roasted coffee, semi sweet chocolate, and fresh cut wood.

Taste:  Roasted coffee, smokey wood flavor, chocolate, and vanilla. Finishes with a little bit of an acidic twang.

Mouthfeel:  Smooth and sparkly.

Overall:  A beautiful smoked beer.  You know its there, it makes the beer stand out, but doesnt overpower. There are lots of other great flavors going on besides the smoke.  I havent quite fallen in love with some of the smokier rauchbiers, which I compare to liquid bacon.  I do love the idea of liquid bacon, I just wouldnt call it a satisfying beer.

Thanks to MrBunn for sharing this. Brown pour with good head. Smells of grain, plums or figs, and maybe a touch of wet dirt. Good flavors matching the nose, but a bit thin at times. Still finishes well.
Bottle with thanks to Andy. Pours brown with a decent head and aromas of wheat, dark fruit, and peat. Flavor is a great mix of chocolate, wheat, cream and earthy peat.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Bottle 35,5 cl. Courtesy of iowaherkey. Pours a clear dark brown with a warm reddish hue and a rough, beige head. Hard roasted malts in the nose with distinct smoke. Surprisingly light - almost a little watery - body with a light underlying tartness. Hard roasted malts with a piquante whiff of smoke. Finishes dry with some malt bitterness. 270509

12 oz bottle courtesy of Discount Liquors (Milwaukee, WI). Pours a very dark pour, nearly black with noticeable red and brown edges, moderate chocolate milk hued head that sticks around at a decent amount, laces fairly well. Aromas are very nice smokiness, ash and burnt wood mix with smoked meats, nothing too powerful, roasted malts mix in well with faint coffee and a smooth mellow feel. Smells great, not overpowering. Initial is has a good body, smooth silky feel with woody ash, light smokey meats, roasted malts, and coffee, moves into more chocolate on the backend that slides down smooth. Light hoppy bitterness for balance, the smoke does not overpower this brew, instead enhancing it a ton. A nice barbeque feel wins me over, with chocolate and coffee coming in on the backend, but roast and firepit ash coming through on the backend as well. A smooth, flavorful smoked porter that doesnt overdo anything. Smooth, flavorful, pretty good smokiness. Quaffable, nothing too big. Kudos to New Glarus AGAIN! Cheers.

UPDATED: MAY 31, 2009 12oz bottle via trade with FlandersNed @ DLD 09. pours a very dark brown with ruby highlights and a thin, light tan head and great lacing. aroma is great with big roast coffee, dark chocolate, burnt wood, a hint of salt pork, and a touch of roasted nuts. flavor is outstanding with big, roast coffee notes up front backed by notes of smoked pork, brown sugar, a pinch of salty bacon, and a nice sweet balance of dark malts and chocolate leaving a lingering smokey, sweet finish. palate is smooth, medium bodied, and a pleasure to drink. overall, a great smoked brew.

12 fl oz bottle. Pours dark brown to black with a small tan head. Light meaty and smoked aroma. Smoked and slight acidic flavoured. Distinct meat note - towards bacon. Bitter, slight acidic and smoked finish.

Bottle giddily purchased from Discount Liquors in Milwaukee - Im happy I scored this one, and was really surprised it was still around. While I cant compare it to what it was like fresh, its drinking just fine right now. And Ill qualify that by saying Im not a big fan of smoked beers -- though I may be seeking more out now. It just looks like something Id want to drink, near black and a fat, frothy tan head. Smell is smoke, meat, chocolate and roasty grains. Taste is smooth roasted malt and smoke -- but the smoke isnt overpowering. Thats really the key for me -- I didnt want to drink a campfire, but they dialed it back just enough to add to the beer without defining it. The only knock I have is that its a little watery, but otherwise I loved it. So happy one of these was still on the shelf after a year and a half!

I was very underwhelmed by this beer. the body was very light. The smoke was there but also light. Ive had way better smoked porters like alaskan smoked porter. I got8 of these on a trade and ended up trading 6 of them away,

Now, it has been a while since I sampled this brew but I have always been a fan of smoked beers. My only complaint with this beer was an acidic astringency that came through which I have noticed in a variety of New Glarus beers. Otherwise, I have good memories. If only New Glarus would make some more.

Bottle thanks to Ofortuna, thanks man!  Poured a deep brown color with some deep ruby edges and a 1/4 inch off-white head that faded to a thin layer and left some spotty lacing.  Aroma of smoke, chocolate, some roast (coffee), and a bit of charred wood.  Smooth, lightly sweet entry with some light hints of meat and brown sugar that gives way to a moderate smokiness with some undertones of chocolate and a soft roastiness that follows into the finish paired with some light lingering smoke.  Low carbonation and smooth on the palate, although a tad thinner that anticipated.  Overall, a very nice, flavorful brew that I wish was regularly available in 6 packs.  Thanks again Dave!

12oz bottle. Nice carbonation. Pours dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is of chocolate, smoke, roasted malt, and grain. Taste is of smoked meat, chocolate, grain, roasted malt, and wood. Lingering meat flavors, with lots of bacon staying long after each sip. Each sip ends very dry, making it all taste like smoked wood. Mouthfeel is very heavily carbonated, which kind of detracts from the beer. A very tasty beer if you like meat and wood.

Dark brown with a frothy beige head that leaves chunks of lace.  Aroma of smoked wood and mild roasted malt.  Taste of smoked wood and mild sweet roasted malt.  Thin and creamy with a semi-dry aftertaste that has some sweetness to it.  Its okay.

courtesy of abends.
pours dark brown, mocha lacing.
Aroma of smoke, malts, roast and bbq with faint touch of chocolate.
Taste was insanely drinkable.
Loaded with good smoke malts, sweet bacon/bbq mouthfeel saturated with smoke and exceptionally well balanced.
This is one well balanced beer, thick palate with the smoke being well used.

Pours chocolate brown in the glass.  Amazing smoke aroma that brings back memories of bon fire keg parties out in a random field.  Flavor is reminiscent of delicious grilled meat.  There are also some chocolate notes.  This beer is awesome.

nose of ultra sweet bacon! saltiness and smoke are there, but a very pleasant sweetness is present as well.  so sweet in fact that it borders on chocolate.  ive never had chocolate covered bacon, but the thought came to mind even before the first sip.  clearly this is the evidence of the combo of malt and smoke -- rarely if ever attempted before.  flavor is a salivating saltiness of smoke unrivaled in its field.  most smoked beers pale in comparison to a real rauch but this stands alone.  appearance is opaque with super lingering head.

i am moving up north, this is ridiculous!!! .. . amazing bbq meaty smokey aroma .. amzing smoky playful flavours .. . thanks to john once again!! .. . black and crazy! still clean.. an awesome awesome treat!!!! did i say amazing!!

Poured a typical brown with small head.  Aroma was smokey dark chocolate.  Flavor was much the same with some coffee flavor as well. Something was a little off in this one for me that i couldnt put my finger on.
This is about smoked, not about porter. There are some porter tastes, but all I get is beautiful smoke and woodiness, that carry you.  Very lovely.  Thanks Phys21ca.
Lots of bacon and smoke. Two things I do not like. I imagine this beer pleases the smoke-fiends. But like the Alaska one, it is not for me. I am kind with my review, knowing Im in a minority.

Bottled sample. Near black in colour with medium carbonation. Aromas are of mild smoke, milk chocolate, and lightly toasted malts. More of the chocolate + smoke combo in the mouth, along with a bit of gunflint, and a touch of fruit. Medium bodied, and fairly dry finishing, Quite nice, especially considering the age of the bottle.

Bottle received from my brother in law as a part of a birthday gift (Thanks Neil!)  Pour was very dark brown with minimal carbonation.  Aroma was rich malts and liquid smoke.  Flavor was meaty, thick, malty and a little sweet on a mellow finish.  A decent smoked beer.

UPDATED: MAR 5, 2009 Pours dark with a thick brown head. Intense smokey aroma and flavor yet  very silky with a hint of chocolate and a light fruitiness. Actually kind of tastes like smoked meat. Taste is very sweet and smooth once you get past the smokiness.

12oz bottle thanks to tayner. Dark black color and an initial smell of smoked meat. The aroma then becomes just smoke without the meat and is allright. The flavor is smoky and peaty but it doesnt take over the nice flavor of the porter. I don;t care much for smoked beers but this one was alright.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-25-2008 04:07:33

Dark brown with ruby highlights and a decent sized beige head. Aroma is of smoke, chocolate and roasted malts.  Flavor is lightly smokey with roasted malts, chocolate, plums and coffee. Flavors blend very well.

A solid pour into my large Tripel Karmeliet tulip glass nets me a two-finger thick, lightly browned, tan colored head.  The beer is quite dark, with a burnt, concentrated brown color.  When held up to the light the beer shows an almost opaque darkness, but does show some flashes of murky, concentrated amber around the edges.  The aroma has the hearty aroma of smoked malt, it smells quite similar to beech-wood smoked malt, though perhaps a touch softer ad less meaty.  Underneath the chewy smoked malt character are notes of roasted grain; a touch of char, a rich toasted whole grain character and as the beer warms a bit, rich notes of dark chocolate and city roast coffee beans.  I really like that the smoke is distinct, dominant even, but doesnt drown out the beautiful dark malt aromatics here.

Fairly light bodied, almost thin in some ways.  The beer is also quite dry tasting up front, with even a touch of roast grain derived acidity to it.  The smoke adds some richness to the flavor, but isnt quite as prominent as it was in the aroma.  The dark, roasted malt notes play a significant, almost leading role here; roasted cocoa, well toasted whole grain bread crust, blackened toffee and, in the finish, a bitter, burnt grain note  and some charred acidity lingers on in the palate.  The smoke seems to accentuate, or perhaps even contribute to a certain sweetness here in the finish.  As the beer warms up it starts to gain in richness and texture; the body has more viscousness to it and it feels fuller as it rolls across the tongue.  The malt sweetness also is magnified as the beer warms up, this works really well with the smokiness and even adds a touch of dark fruit character up front.

This is quite a nice beer.  I really like the mix of flavors from the smoked and the roasted malt mix.  My biggest complaint is that a 12oz bottle is not nearly enough of this for one sitting.  This is one of those beers that started out a bit slow, but finished up great.
A great departure from the cherry rut Dan Cleary has been in with his unplugged. Sweet beer, you can smell and taste the smoked flavor though.  Nice beer for the fireside.

Bottle, received in a trade.  Black pour with some brown head.  Aroma is sweet toffee. sweet chocolate, roast, light meaty smokiness, and cola.  flavor is the same, nice sweetness and the smoked aspects take a little bit of a back seat to everything else.

Bottle: Poured a clear black color porter with a nice foamy head with good retention and great lacing. Aroma consists of light smoke with some notes of light coffee. Taste is a nice mix between some creamy roasted coffee notes with a lingering smoke final.  Body is a bit light for the style with some good carbonation. Some additional smoke and a fuller body would have improved this beer in my mind but still is a great achievement as is.

12oz bottle, from 2008 Secret Santa (thanks!). Pours deep brown, capped with a moderate sized tan head. Aroma of mild chocolate, cocoa, caramel, and bacon. Flavor is bakers chocoate, caramel malt, and smoke. Smoke and mildly bitter chocolate linger on the palate. Very smooth bodied and incredibly easy to drink.
Brown/black pour with a decent tan head and lace. Peaty smoke aroma. Peaty, burnt coffee with a good bitter finish. Creamy full and rich body. Very solid a hint of over carb held my score back a tad.
Very smoky.  I like a beer that finally delivers the smoke after touting it.  Good porter characteristics, malty, roasty, a little chocolate.  Easy to drink.

12 oz bottle from KingpinIPA, thanks man. Pours a solid brown black body with a super huge foamy beige head. Aroma of hickory smoked wood, bitter sweet bakers chocolate and roasted malts. Medium bodied, light carbonation and an oily mouthfeel. Flavor of burnt chemical smokiness, lots of dark malts, dark chocolate, slight sourness in the mix. One solid beer and probably my favorite from the Unplugged series so far.
Really enjoyed this brew.  Smoke flavor throughout, very easy drinking.  Would drink again.
Bottle. Smells like a campfire. Tastes like smoke, malt with some oak present. A nice example of a smoked beer.

Bottle courtesy of theisti. Pours a deep brown with garnet highlights and a thin tan skin of bubbles that deposits patchy lace on the glass. The nose is of smokey malt and sweet toffee. Light-bodied and aqueous with a slightly astringent, drying finish. Sweet, smokey malt and toffee; more-or-less follows the nose. This is a solid, drinkable smoked brew. Thanks again, Tim.
Smell is smoke, beef jerky, wood, dark malts, and meaty.  Smell is like a meal.  Dark brown to black in color with a good tan head.  Taste is dark malts, coffee, chocolate, roasty, and smoke. Good.

12oz. bottle, with thanks to Gregis.  Pours a dark brown with a minimal tan head, minimal lacing. Aroma is smoky, slightly meaty, with a light roastiness. Flavor is more of the same. Well balanced, slightly watery, and not overpowering on the smoke.  Well done and enjoyable, thanks for the chance to finally try this Greg!

12 ounce bottle shared by cdumler. Thanks Chris! Pours black with a medium dark brown head. Decent lacing and retention. Big smoky aroma with notes of peat and roasted malts. Very similar taste with some grainy and caramel notes. Medium bodied.

Bottle. Big smoke nose with light chocolate notes and caramel/tootsie roll character. Black with a thin brown head but great lacing. Good smoke presence through the whole palate, among chocolate flavors and roastiness. Very clean palate with a slightly smoky harshness that is more assertive than offensive. Nice and clean all around.

12 oz. bottle - thanks to drewbeerme for the trade; cola brown with thick, tan head; roasty aromas a balanced mix of smoke and chocolate; the smoke adds richness and smoothness without being overpowering; wow, a very tasty porter; flavors of chocolate and nuts; a silky smooth drinker; ymmmm, how i love these midwest porters!!
(Bottle)  Pours a dark brown body with a small tan head.  Aroma of wood, smoke, roasted malt, and some chocolate.  Flavor of smoked meat, chocolate, light vanilla, and roasted malt.

Bottle thanks to Bu11zeye. Pours a deep dark brown with tan head. Aroma is smokey and dark roast. Flavor is smokey, dark roast, with a faint sweetness. Light-med. body with high carbonation. Overall, tasty porter!

Pours black with off-white head that reeks of burnt wood.   Aroma is burnt wood, liquid smoke, and more smoke.  Flavor is smoke but finished with some kind of copenhagen chew flavor.  Very smoked but not as big as I would like with the flavor.  My favorite all time is Alaskan  this would be up there is they just balanced the smoked a little more.  Otherwise a very drinkable and quite enjoyable.

Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. Let me say that smoked beers are far down the ladder on my favorite styles, but this pulls it off decently. Dark brown body with an off-white head. Aroma of tar, smoke, chicory, jerky (beef) and coffee. Taste is smokey with coffee and chcolate, meat and tobbacco. Slightly fizzy (which comes across oddly) with a water like mouthfeel.

Dark chocolate and roasted malt aroma. Savory, piny, and  smoky. 
Pours cola like. Watery dark brown with a creamy frothy head. 
Tastes like bbq. Smokey, caramel, and chocolate. A wonderful blend of flavors. Though there isn’t much complexity but very smooth and enjoyable.

Bottle.  Great aroma - rich, clean smoke over a dark chocolate base.  Not astringent.  The flavor continues the trend of a dark chocolate & smoke core but adds on roast malt.  A damn fine smoked beer.  My bottle might be showing a little age with some oxidation in the finish but that also could be the dark malts.

Im sorry - call me a sucker for smokey things. I love Texan BBQ - or well, anyones BBQ. This stuff is SMOKEY. Nose is smoke. Has notes of alder, pine, manzanita, bamboo, redwood and oak.  Seriously - I have BBQd with all of these woods and I know their characteristics. They are all here.  Ends on a nice, dry note. I think I need a growler of this stuff.

Bottle acquired via trade with iowaherkeye...Joey is the man!!!  Dark mahogany pour with a latte brown head.  This beer is definitely unique...can definitely taste the smoke (a subtle rauchbier quality)...not overwhelming but undoubtedly present.  Flavor exhibits the dark roasted coffee and bitter chocolate from its porter roots.  A bit thin...Alaskan’s Smoked Porter is significantly better!!!

Bottled. Nice brown head on nearly black beer. Dark roasty aroma has touches of chocolate and a bit of toasted pumpernickel sourness. Moderate roasty bitterness, very light touch of sweetness. Smoke is incredibly subtle, but it’s there blended in with the roast. Medium body at best with fairly lively mouthfeel, a bit dry. Nice stuff.

bottle thnks to iowaherkeye.  black color with a small beige head.  smells like smoked meat and a good porter. just like it should. flavor is smokey and malty with a decent  hop profile.  I get a good roasted flavor and smoke. Very interesting and worth trying for sure.

Pour is black with a thin tannish head...smell is richly smokey with cmoked sausage and bacon along with a hint of chocolate at the end....taste is not nearly as smokey as the nose...the first thing is the cocoa and coffee, giving way to some smoke along with it...the smoke stays pretty constant when the cocoa comes back out in the finish...tasty for sure!

12oz bottle. Pours dark brown with thick and creamy light tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, chocolate and smoked peat. Flavor is chocolate, roasted malts, smoke and coffee. Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy like a porter. Smoke does not overwelm flavor and adds a nice complexity. Smoked is not my favorite style and I cannot imagine it getting any better than this.

Bottle from Grimreeser. Pour brown/black with a nice tan head, spotty lacing. Aroma of chocolate and smoky peat. Medium to full bodied with a silky and creamy texture. Flavor of milk chocolate and dark roasted malts, countered by a moderate (but no overdone) smokiness. Average attenuation, that balances this out nicely. Finish is smooth and milky, with notes of tobacco. Nice!

Bottle big thanks to Hopdog. Pours pretty near black with a good looking head and very dense lacing. The aroma is meaty enough, I suppose, with hints at earth, nutshells, and coffee. The mouthfeel is surprisingly light for a porter, but it works all right here. Dark chocolate and tame coffee mix well with the meat flavor. The finish is the best thing about this beer. It is creamy with a strangely sweet smokiness that I’m really digging along with a bit of ash. I really like this beer, but it needs more smoke.
Bottle at Sunes (Thanks). Black (red glow) - white head. High smoley, roasted, dryness, chocolate, low carbonation. Light thin body. OK !!
pours a dark brown with mild head, mild sweet aroma, smoky back to finish, complex background, obvious smoke presence.

A black appearance with a beige head. The aroma is smokey with some charcoal, coffee, and chocolate. The flavor is also smokey with some hints of bacon and coffee. The finish is rather bitter. I love smoked beers in moderation and this one was well done.

Bottle from monger, thanks james! Aroma of malt, spicy peppers? and chocolate. Big head that took a while to settle. Color is dark black. Taste is roasted malt, hint of chocolate and smoke. Very smooth, low carbonation. Good beer.

Bottles from alexgash, iowaherkeye and d0b.  Thanks! 
Pours almost black with a bit of light getting through and a beige head.  Smell is nicely smoky, but it mixes and mingles well with a roasted coffee flavor.  Nice.  Taste is nicely rich and malty with light smokiness and coffee flavor.  Some lingering light smoke in the finish.  Average body and carbonation.  Really a solid smoked beer, and quite enjoyable.

bottle from the bockeyhorseys... pours barely transparent ruby black with a light hot cocoa colored head and lots of drippy lacing. aroma is surprisingly full of vanilla and  fudgey chocolate in front of mellow (should have figured apple wood) campfire woody char and some sourness from it. the flavor is very controlled... not overly smoked so that nothing else is tasted. chocolate, roasty/malty grain, some lemon or grapefruit, a little bit of spice and a tart smoky finish. lightly smoked chocolate makes it’s way into the aftertaste. this is one of the softest, subtle,  least ’meaty’ smoked beers i’ve had. medium body with a great mouth feel... so creamy from the smooth carbonation...

Pours a very dark brown in color with a nice inch of head forming on the pour.  Smell is roasty smoke flavor.  Taste is more of the same.   But it’s not a campfire smoky flavor.  This is a nice roasty, smoked meat kind of flavor.  And it’s done incredibly well.  Decent mouthfeel.  One of the better smoked beers that I’ve had.

@ home with the club. Pours a clear dark brown with an off-white head. Smoked malt aromas. Very well balanced. Soft carbonation. Medium to light bodied. Very good. Big thanks to Kimber who sent me this from Wisconsin.

Thanks to lb4lb for throwing this bottle my way. Thanks Deniz!  Pours medium brown with a light brown head that leaes some nice lacing.  Aroma is cocoa, roast, smoky bacon, and more smoke.  Flavor is huge smoky bacon, chocolate, fruity, and roasted malts.  I’m usually not a big fan of smoked beers but I really like the balance of this one.  Palate is on the thin side but carbonation is nice and smooth.

Bottle:  Dark brown pour...notes of brown sugar, chocolat malt and fn smoked bacon...blah.  Medium-light body does not compliment this brew in the slightest.  Flavor consists of smoked meats, liquid smoke, some chocolate and dark malts.  Way oversmoked IMO.

Bottle, dimple mug.  Dark brown pour, opaque in the glass, with a moderate amount of a creamy beige head.  This dissipates to leave a bit more than lacing: it practically coats the glass!  Aromas of chocolate first, then smoke and carbonation.  Similar initial flavors, chocolate, cola, bacony smoke.  The mouthfeel is creamy on the tongue but not at all thick; it swallows a little watery.  As it warms, the chocolate becomes less pronounced, and the smoke gains some breadth, not so much bacon, more peat and aniseed.  A sweet-sour plum element arises, too, particularly upon licking the lips.  Finish is both bitter and earthy.

Thanks to bwkrieger for this gem. Black with thin head. Smoky aroma fits with the sweet malt and smokey mix in the taste. Very generous roast/smoke with a little bit of molasses. A little less sweetness would kick it up another notch, but this is still right up my alley.

Thanks to decaturstevo for sharing this one.
Mostly black with a firm tan head.
Smoky aroma.
Sweet, smooth, nicely smoked.  Good balance of flavors.

Sweet chocolaty malt aroma with some vanilla and citrus.  Dark brown with a slight orangish tint, foamy head of decent duration. Flavors of deep roasted malt, caramel, vanilla, light smokiness not overbearing, some dark chocolate.  Light sweet focus and balance.  Very good flavor. Mild to light palate and mild sweet duration.  Very good.

In short: A very fruity and very smoky porter.  Very good.
How: Bottle 12oz.  One of the bottle I got from the simultaneous generosity of mreush, ughsmash, Stine and Kingpinipa.  A conspiracy Im telling you!!!
The look: Black body topped by a very small tan head
In long: Nose is very smoky on top of rich molasses.  Taste is a whole bunch of fruits in molasses.  The fruity flavours here go way beyond the usual porters dark fruits.  Grapes, berries, figs and even some lighter dessert fruits such as pineapples and kiwis providing a nice tartness.  Smoke is there and roastiness level is moderate but its really the fruit flavours that come out the most here.  A little hard-candy sweetness.  Everything comes together very well in this beer.  Smoky but not too much, complex fruitiness, lively carbonation, light astringency in the finish, nice roastiness and molasses backbone.  A very good beer.  As fruity and smoked as my senile aunt Lucie on medicinal marijuana.

poured from 12 oz bottle., dark and malty with slight smoke in the nose.  definitley a lot less smoke than I was expecting, but definitely there.  opaque black in glass with no lacing.  as it warms a slight burnt smell, reminding me of smoked salmon.  taste is smooth and well balanced, not a lot of roasted malt flavor which lets the smoke come through

Bottle from Ryan.  Thanks.   I have been saving this one until smoked food was on the menu for the evening, and low and behold, that was Saturday.  Pours out a nice dark brown color with a tan head on it.  Pretty much what I was expecting on appearance.  Smell is smoky, roasted, but mostly just smoke.  Smells like my ribs, in a way - only not as good.  Taste is smooth and somewhat thin, light on the chocolate tastes, but heavy on the smoke.  Not so much a Rauchbier, but more of a pleasant experience similar to that of Alaskan Smoked.  Good stuff, but not something I would want to drink alot of - smoked beers are not my forte.   Still worth trying and definitely worth drinking.

12oz. bottle.  Nose is roasty and smoky, dark and full of rich chocolate and espresso, some lighter earthiness and old wood to be found as well.  Utterly opaque black color with a lasting, fine, light tan head.  Flavor is full of dry, roasted and bitter maltiness, charry smoke, burnt sugars and faint touches of tart fruit and spicy hop bitterness towards the finish.  Palate is thin with a low-moderate degree of effervescence and a medium-full body.  Woody smoke lingers far into the aftertaste.  Really a nice blend of elements here.  Cheers to theisti!
Sampled at the Carolina Crew gathering in Greenville.  Dark brown pour with a small head.  Lightly smokey, roasty aroma.  Very chocolatey, coffee, and smokey.  Very good stuff.

WOW!!!  12 oz bottle poured a deep brown color.  Nice tan head formed a craggy top to the glass.  Stuck around for a while.  The best aroma from a smoke beer that I have had.  Sweet malt taste with smoke and a grassy bitterness to match the malt.  Some bread-like qualities.  Some caramel and toffee in there as well.  A small smoke aftertaste comes after the swallow.  Would like to try on draft and get some more!

Very dark brown pour sporting a tan head that disappates quickly.  The nose is moderately smoky...allright, maybe a bit more than moderately.  I love the style anyway.  First flavor is smoke on top of a roasty dark malt sweetness.  Touches of hop bitterness play well against the lingering chocolate and coffee notes.  Very nice beer with grilled foods and is mild enough that it wouldn’t  overpower   a smoky cedar-planked salmon steak.

Tasted at the Carolina Crew gathering, Greenville - thanks to whomever shared these two bottles.  Dark brown pour thin off-white head. Smoked malt aroma.  Coffee, and roast with a sweet smokey finish.  Slightly over shadowed by the 2004 alaskan smoked porter i had the same night.

From Bottle : Pours dark brown with hints of red inside.  About one finger of off white head.  A smokey roasted coffee smell, very nice.  Taste has alot alike with the smell, smokey coffee being the main idea.  Quite smooth going down and not to thick.  Very enjoyable aftertaste of roastedness.  I’ve had this one sitting around waiting to be consumed for quite awhile now, and it was worth the wait.

Thanks James for the bottle.  Dark brown pour with light tan head and amazing lacing. Smells and tastes of coffee, anise, bitter chocolate, charred wood, and smoked meats -- though not greasy tasty.  Creamy, a little sweet, and pleasantly bitter.  Did not expect I’d like this as I’m neither a porter or a smoked beer fan.  Damn good beer.

Bottle, courtesy Gillard. Dark brown pour, red highlights, thin hazy head, decent lacing. Big smoky nose, with some BBQ, roasted notes deep in the nose. Flavor is smoky obviously, but more subtle than the nose. Roasted malt comes in big, with a fairly decent hop sting in the finish. Tasty, thin-bodied but nice and drinkable. Surprisingly refreshing for the style.
This was a awesome beer. Poured a nice dark Brown, has a great smokey aroma and roasty taste.

Pours a nice dark dark brown with a tan head. Aroma is almost all smoke with some coffee and oak chips mixed in. Flavor is very smokey, reminds me much of east end smokestack. I think im a sucker for this style.

Well, all right!  I have been looking forward for some time to trying something from this RateBeer favorite, and thanks to Adrian, now I can.  There is a humble, hand-sketched drawing on the label, along with a mouth-watering description of the brewing process.  Dark pour and foamy head.  Woah - a pungent, noticable, complex aroma: coffee, floral, citrus.  The flavor is equally exciting - solid coffee taste, sweet malts, and fruit.  Then comes a real kicker - gentle hops and a rich sort of wood smoke, reminiscent of campfires and tasty smoked meat.  A little weird, but it works out very nicely!  Mouthfeel is velvety and lightly carbonated.  The flavor is full and well-balanced, not harsh or syrupy.  This is an eccentric American classic!

12oz bottle.  Pours black with a thin tan head which dissipated quickly.  Smell is smoky meat, bacon to be precise.  Mmm!  Smoke is not overpowering.  Taste is of roasted malt and also smoky meat.  Mouthfeel is medium-to-thin and watery, just like many other porters.  has a little bitterness in the finish.  Although I am not a fan of smoky beers, this one was not a turnoff, but rather enjoyable.  Thanks to the BA trader who sent it.

Really, really nice smoke aroma in this beer.  Not overpowering, blends in flawlessly with the light porter flavor.  That might be the only complaint, that the flavor isnt more intense, that and the thinner mouthfeel too.

This creamy beer pours a deep dark copper colour with a beautiful flowing tan head. Aroma of smoke, chocolate malts, roasted nuts, oak and honey. flavor is exceptionally tastey. Very ripe fruit flavors, cinammon with a nice silky texture and a full carbonated mouthfeel.

Pours a dark, dark brown with mahogany hints around the edges.  The off-white head is small and dissipates quickly leaving very little lacing.

Smoke comes out immediately in the smell - a hickory smoked bacon aroma that doesnt overpower.  The sweet malts are in the background as well with a little coffee and chocolate.

The smoke is a little less evident up front in the taste with the sweetness of roasted malts and molasses hitting first.  This gives way to a bit of the chocolate and dark fruits before the smoke makes itself felt in the finish, lingering nicely.

Mouthfeel is medium bodied with decent carbonation and a tad dry in the finish.

The smoke taste in this beer is subtle an doesnt overpower.  As such, this is very well balanced smoked porter and one that I could drink all night.

[Bottle] shared by EddyB23. Pours deep brown with a medium off white head. Aroma is very smoky and smokey, with some coffee note in there as well. Bittersweet flavor with plenty of smoked meats. Very smooth flavor, and by far one of my favorite smoked beers.

Bottle from Bockyhorsey. The pour was brownish with some reddish hues. The head was a little weak, but ok. The aroma was meaty smoke flavors over top of a roasted dark malt choco-coffee blend. The flavor followed the aroma, some more coffee and roast than chocolate. When all is said and done, I dont like the meaty smokes mixed in with the porter elements - the rauch-edness seems to work better with lager and marzen base beers much better. Thanks, Bill, for the great opportunity, though, always indebted to you for your kindness.

(bottle) Pours dark brown with a cream colored head.  Aroma contains a lot of smoke, with definite roasted malt, and the scent of salty bacon and campfire as well.  Taste is chocolate up front followed by a nice smoky, chocolate, and roasted malt finish that lasts for awhile.  The aroma and finish of this beer are great, but the flavor is somewhat lacking.

Dark brown pour with a small off-white lace - fairly strong smoke in the aroma, complimented well by the roasted malt - light notes of sweet cream underneath - soft mouthfeel, medium body - bitter coffee and cocoa in the flavor - the smoke doesnt come through as much as the aroma suggests it will - just a little sweet, mostly drying out in the finish and getting fairly bitter, developing light tobacco notes - just okay.

Pours out black with a thick tan head. Big smoked wood, meat aroma, very campfire like. Lots of Bamberg in the aroma. Taste is malty, smoky, with a hint of some spice. A little creaminess keeps everything smooth. Leaves a slight smokiness on the tongue afterwards. Not a fan of the style, but this is delicious.

Pours black with a small creamy beige froth.  Aroma of smoke, creamy chocolate, some dark fruits and a hint of alcohol.  Flavor of smokey bacon, creamy dark chocolate and light coffee bitterness.  Mos bacon bar?  A nice smoked, but not nearly as interesting as I was expecting... needs more smoke! Creamy but light body some larger carbonation bubbles.   A solid, complete brew, that is very well balanced.

I should have known better.  I am just not a fan of smoked beers, but I have liked most of New Glarus products so I gave this one a shot.  It smells like a big glass full of smoked meat.  The smoke aroma is very strong.  Pours a deep brown color with almost no head.  Flavor is significantly less meaty than the aroma.  Actually has a good malt backbone that isnt completely overpowered by the smoke.  Probably my last smoked beer.  Just not my style.  This is the best of the ones Ive sampled though.

Bottle. Dark brown almost black, almost no head.Strong aroma of malt and smoke blended together. Thick to the palate.nice malt taste at first but tastes too smokey after that. Would be a better beer if not so smokey.

Bottle, bought November 07. Meant to get to this sooner, but it got involved with a trade that got broken in shipment, and next thing I knew, I was down to two bottles, but oh, well Smell is not the phenol explosion of a Schenklera. A bit of campfire smoke instead of bacon in the nose, deep brown porter in glass with a thin, almost creamy looking tan head. Being at least seven months old may affect this bottle; I get a nice roast porter profile, with a bit of smoke coming on on a secondary wavelength. Foam stays creamy like an oatmeal stout. Background of coffee, maybe some oak, and roast pepper. Easy drinking and likable.

bottle, at Carolina Crew get together. Not sure who brought it.  Smokey, peat, roasted grain, little banana, caramel. Dark orangy brown color, good head & lace. Bitter flavor, like aroma, smoke mostly dominates. Little nutty. Lite body, creamy smooth mouthfeel, smooth smoke finish. Didnt excite me. Seemed like an ok porter, smoke was moderate. Eh
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Pours very dark, cannot even see through it up to light. The aroma is amazing. Smells like bacon, very very savory aroma, makes my mouth water.The flavor is quite complex as well. Tastes much like it smells, also some roasted nut, and malt flavors, and a slight bit of caramel. This is a very impressive beer. I love new glarus, hats off to them.
Aroma is of smoked meat, campfire-ish.  Too dark in appearance for my taste.  I taste some chocolates, and wood.  I love the full body.

The Dan Journal #179.  Tasted 5/30/08.  12oz bottle.  Murky brown hue.  Lacing beige head.  Crazy aromas of bacon and chocolate.  Fudgy smokey nose.  Full bodied.  Tart and sweet with a touch burnt maltiness.  Tart cherry estery note.  Nice English style base porter.  Good cocoa note.  The smoke is subtle and almost perfect!

The aroma is smoky, and meaty witht light hints of roasted malts, and a little caramel sweetness. The color is a very deep brown with a fluffy white head. Considering the very smoky aroma, I expected this beer to taste a little smokier, however at the front of the mouth this brew just tastes like a really fantasic porter with great flavors of chocolate, cherry, oak, & coffee. However mid-mouth the flavor gets intensley more smokey with better woody and meaty flavors. The beer finishes with a good dryness. 
The texture is creamy and smooth.

Small tan head with fair retention and some scant spotty lacing. Clear, amber brown color. Nose of light smoke, wood and maybe some chocolate. Body is almost medium, lightly oily on the palate. Gentle smoke flavors up front followed by notes of roast, chocolate, caramel and cocoa, fairly dry all around. Finish is almost dry, smokey and lingering. A kinder, gentler smoked brew imho. Props to captaincougar for the bottle, thanks Tom!

Shared at the Carolina Gathering. Pours a dark brown that allows a tad bit of light. Has a thin creamy light tan head. Has a very nice smokey meaty aroma to it. The flavor is similar, very meaty, a well balanced smoke characteristic, a bit coppery, flavor is a tad thin. Had a decent mouthfeel and a smokey meaty finish.

bottle: pours a dark brown almost black with a thick foamy tan head. aroma is definetly smoke woth some chocolate behind it and just a little roast. flavour is a little weaker than i expected some good smoke adn sutle chocolate a very dry roast in the finish that seems to linger. not bad at all ilike thesmoke it is just about right.
Thanks fordest. Bottle. Very dark pour, almost black with a very small head . Aroma is of smoke. Taste is smokey with some chocolate. Very enjoyable.
Pour is deep black/brown, minimal head. Nose is smoky, though not as rich and intense as Id expect. Taste is a bit chocolaty and roasted. Not getting as much smoke as Id like. Nice though.
Am I drinking ham? Yeah, I think I am. It pours an almost opaque black. Aroma of smoked meat, sausage, chocolate. Taste is Chocolate smoked liquid ham.

black pour with a very small off white head.  wow it really seems like i could take a bite of this stuff.  the smell is so smokey, its like having a glass of bbq.  nice and easy on the palate and the flavors dont really change much from the smell.  i need to get some more of this stuff very soon.

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2009 This is a great beer, and I would love to pair this with some grilled meats.  A generous, gamey meaty nose.  I love it, I want to take a bite out of it.  Has that campfire smell of coffee roasted over an open fire, tastes like it too.  Roasty with some nutty chocolate notes.  Its still a porter, but it brewed by Dan and that adds a lot of character.  Thanks Jbuzz

Bottle.  This may very well be one of my favorite porters.  Pours a black color with some brown hues.  Head is an off white tan color about 1 finger in depth.  Aroma is vanilla and smoked malt, mouth watering.  Taste is just that with no acrid hop or etoh in the finish.  Fantastic porter!

12 oz bottle.  Pours a dark brown body with a bit of highlights on the edges when held to the light.  Foamy and fizzy beige head that faded to a thin wispy film.  A nice combination of smoke, chocolate and roastiness on the nose.  A little too well balanced for my tastes, Id like to see the smoke out front a little more.  The smoke is pretty muted on the flavor, theres a lot more chocolate and roasted malt than smoked.  Really tasty and flavorful, but not as smoky as I was hoping for.  Theres a good bit of smokiness late on in the finish though, with just a touch of smoked meat notes.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with a texture that would pass for creamy were it not for the slightly overactive fizzy carbonation.  Overall, a wonderful drinker, and certainly flavorful, but I found it left the Smoked beer lover in me a little unsatisfied.

Bottle.    mmm..mmm this is some good shit!  Aroma is nice, not too shy with the smoke and it really shines witt a spicy roast malt.  Creamy light brown head that laces, opaque.  Sweet and smokey with a dry malt finish with hints of smoke.  Not BBQ in a glass but a nice balance of smoke with the sweet roast porter character.  Full bodied and creamy.  Excellent.
12oz bottle. Poured a deep and dark brown color with an off white head. Aromas of roast, chocolate, toffee and smoke (not over powering). Tastes of chocoalte, smoke roast, vanilla, and coffee.

thanks to cmubeerman for the bottle he left behind for me.  this poured fast and light, very thin elegant pearl white head with a Slimer-looking film in the middle atop a pretty opaque black body. aroma is clearly smoked but with a fair amount of wood, beech i presume. my nose is a bit clogged, so its showing through pretty well. not as meaty as others.  light bodied, clean, completely tolerable, mild smoky flavor, not meaty at all, excellent for the style. brilliant.

Pours a dark amber with a brief head and a pungent, meaty, smoked flavour. Thin, smoky a bit roasty, a bit watery and nothing much else. Good carbonation, good body, not a bad beer, but not particularly rich or complex. Thanks to Ughsmash for the secret-santa trade!
Talk about smoked.  Tastes like Tom Waits vocal chords with some ham thrown in.
Pours a dark brown with a foamy tan head. Lacing is present. Aroma is mostly roasted grain. Tastes of smoked grains, slight lactose taste, little vanilla. Palate is creamy and roasty.
In a bottle.  Very smoky, but goes down smooth.  It is a bit too carbonated for my liking but overall is very well crafted beer.  Has a great after taste and great body.
BOTTLE! this beer when you pop open the bottle smells very similar to guiness. though the taste is much different. its very smokey and is very creamy.

Bottle, its nice to be back in Wisconsin and be able to find New Glarus again. Very smoky aroma. Nice deep brown color with a   creamy head. Good malt aftertaste that couples with the smoke to make this beer incredibly drinkable. Would buy again
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: Bottle thanks to CMUBEERMAN. Pours charcoal, slight ruby tones if held in the sunlight. Aroma is smoke, ham, honey, pineapple. Flavor is the same with malt and slight hops. This is a pretty smooth, smoky damn good beer.

UPDATED: APR 24, 2008 Bottle thanks to Drnk_McDermott. Pours a deep brown with a decent beige head. The aroma is smoky bacon and some malt. The flavor is also quite smoky with a bunch of toasted malts. Also, some hops and chocolate. Nice. Would be great with some ham or turkey. Hell, with anything.

Roughly 3 oz. pour from a 12 oz. bottle, consumed at a beer tasting on 4-12-08. Smoky, yeasty aroma. Campfire, sausage, and milk chocolate scents (think smores without the marshmallow). Pours dark brown with a red hue. Large amount of dark beige to light tan head. Good lacing. Smoke in the attack and the finish; porter in the mid-palate. This is smokier than most smoked porters and smokier than I expected. Medium body. Surprisingly soft in the palate. Im a sucker for a good smoked beer, and New Glarus Smoke on the Porter certainly qualifies.

Thanks to fantomas!  Sweet roasted malts, creamy aromas with hints of smoke.  Pours Dark brown with a thick tan head that slips away quickly.  Smooth chocolate malts, creamy mouthfeel, roasted malts, not overly smokey but just enough to give this porter a leg up on the others!

12 oz. bottle purchased at Chicones in Hudson, Wisconsin.  Pour is dark brown with ruby highlights.  Nice one inch tan head which is lasting.  Lacing on glass is pretty.
