Aroma is roastiness primarily, and some wet campfire.  Taste is mostly about the malted smokiness, finishing with a bitter hoppiness which is nice.  The smokiness is very mouth coating, very much like drinking heavily roasted coffee.  Medium palate, good drinkability. Overall, this was decent smoked beer but not terribly complex.

A Mes rate: Bottle at Toms UGT Pt. 2.Almost black mahogany colour with a very good tan head. Rich smoky malt all round. The Bamberg influence is clear, and dare I say it, in bottle form at least, possibly a touch better. I generally go weak at the knees for good smoked beer and this one is bloody awesome.

Bottle:  This poured deep brown with a tan head.  No surprise, the smoke showed prominently along with chocolate.  I really enjoyed how this was more of a campfire/BBQ smoke and didnt knock you over the head.  The palate was smooth and medium-bodied with fresh carbonation.

Dark brown pour with a creamy head.  Light smoky flavor combine with a cocoa flavor.  I actually prefer smoked beers with the subtle smokiness to them versus the brash in your face variety.  This beer almost doesnt have any smoked qualities to it, so in that sense, I almost feel let down.  As I drink more of this, I start to notice more meaty and even a little spice kick towards the finish.  That makes it at least an interesting beer.  Decent.

12oz from pantanap - thanks, Kan!! Oh yeah, a big pit roastin aroma, one that seems to combine the quirky spicing of a traditional ale with the qualities of what my wife calls "meat beer." Dark brown pour with a somewhat slight head, body a bit too thin to sustain the style (for my taste). But the flavor is robust, with a nice malty porter at the core. A good one.
Pours cola black with a medium beige/light brown head.  Aroma of malt, cocoa and smoked meat.  Taste of sweet malty cocoa with hints of jerky and smoke.

Pours to a really dark brown body with a thin light beige head.  The aroma is very, very nice.  Creamy chocolate porter notes up front with a subtle smoked wood/malt.  Seems like it uses oatmeal too.  Beechwood or applewood smoke.  Salted meat and juniper berries.  Spruce hops.  The flavor is very balanced with sweet milk chocolate, acetic smoked malts, juniper berries, and spruce hops.  Things in this reminds of the Norwegian Wood beer.  The palate is perhaps a touch over-carbonated and leaves my mouth watering with a thin, slick body thats dry and astringent.

Bottle courtesy of iowaherkeye. The pour reveals a deep, dark brown color with medium brown highlights and a thick, frothy tan head. The aroma is smokey, the smoked ham Bamberg style smokey that I love, underneath the heavy smoked malt, some coacoa/chocolate notes were detected. The flavor is solid, theres more balance between the smoked malt and the coacoa/chocolate notes so it feels less like a rauchbier and more like what a smoked porter should be, in the end some dryness is felt and the smoke feels a bit woody. The body is light to medium with a creamy texture and moderate carbonation. This smoked porter is really good.

Nice sipping beer, little too thin bodied, but still solid.  Poured thin and dark brown, smelled like smoke.  Tastes like smokey malt with slight hints of chocolate coming through.  Decent beer, but nothing to get excited about.
Bottle at lucky pieres indoor bbq while accidently forgetting to turn on the air conditioning. Alround im not going to lie here: Like teabagging a bbq. This is one smokey beast.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2008 this beer was great and is only sold in wisconsin,thank god i dont live far from the border. poured black with average dark tan head with lots of lacing. aromas of smoke ,coffee .taste of mild smoke and sweetness i think from chocolate not very thick,but very smooth and clean

Bottle at Magic_dave6s disco dance tasting. Very dark ruby with a thin off-white head. Burnt malty aroma, chocolate, plenty of bite. Mouth is a bit smoky, that catches the back of the throat, malty and very drinkable. Very good.

Not a fan of Rauchbiers and this one leaned too much in that direction.  Poured out nice and dark, almost black, with a full tan head.  The aroma was ash.  Folks talk of bacon, but I dont get it.  I LOVE bacon, the smell of it, the taste of it.  But I never get that in heavily smoked beers.  I get the aroma of ashes and a flavor akin to adding water to the bottom of your grill after cooking.  This wasnt quite that bad but the smoke didnt have the subtlty of ofther smoked beers Ive enjoyed.  Couldnt get past it in the aroma or the flavor to really enjoy this brew but it wasnt as bad as the Rauschbiers Ive endured.
Deep brown ... oh yeah definitly smokey and some roast malts ... again lots of good solid roast malts with quite a  relaxed smokeyness, that increases in intensity in its swollow.

12 oz bottle via Mys Swap 3.0 (thanks monger!). Been looking forward to this one. Pours near black with a large tan head. Nose is of course smoky...so smokey that i dont get anything but smoke! AS for the taste, there is what i THINK to be some roastiness under the smoke, as well as a bit of sour cherry and chocolate, and perhaps some raisin. The smoke dominates but is not overkill though. Body is medium and carbonation is moderate. This is one of the better smoked beers i have had.

Aroma is so woodsy and smoky.  Very nice chocolate, cocoa aroma too. 
Taste is slightly sour, woodsy, touch watery.  However, very nice.  
Finish is woodsy, lingers.  Doesnt sour on the finish, like Id expect.

Thanks to terminus for sharing this smoked porter.  Pours dark brown with a brownish hue and deep tan head.  The aroma has lots of smoked malt with wood and peat, some chocolate and only light amounts of bacon.  Medium body with moderate carbonation between soft and sharp.  The flavor starts off with smoky malt, some chocolate and clean roast.  The finish is clean and lighter than expected.  Not my favorite style by a long shot, but it is good for what it is.
thanks to ilanman for donating this to the cause.  scent is strong with smoke, chocolate and malts.  taste is not as strong as the scent, but is still very good.

Bottle Yes another Unplugged some day i will have rated them all. Any how This one pours out a dark brown almost black with a little red. Topepd with a off white cream head. A nice aroma of light roast and light smoke. Tast of light smoke and some more of that roast malt. Pretty nice. Thanks Jake65 for letting me have some of this.

12 oz bottle from UncleJedi - thanks John! Pours near black with a light brown head. Chocolaty nose, big, woody smokiness. Flavors of dry semisweet chocolate and smoky wood, lightly earthy. Body is smooth, a tad thin, but not by much. Very drinkable! A bit of coffee comes through in the smoky finish. Good stuff!
Funky meaty aftertaste and  a bit too sweet at points.  One of the better smokes but still not a favorite.

12oz bottle.  Pours normal looking porter color with a generous tan head.  Aroma is immediately smoky and nice.  I dont want to say this is unsubtle because its not overwhelmingly smoky, but its definitely more assertive than a lot of smoke beers Ive had.  The smokiness doesnt cover up the nice roasty, chocolatey porter characteristics, which is nice.  In addition, the smokiness is a nice crisp, appetizing smelling smoke.  Not overly phenolic or peaty.  Taste is smooth, medium bodied, smoky with a nice long dry finish.  Certainly one of the best smoked beers if not the best Ive ever had.

12-oz. Thanks, Theisti! Black. Dense but shallow tan creamy head. Huge smokey, bacony nose. Watery, somewhat flat body. Lots of smoke, roast, bacon, and chocolate on the mid-palate. Long smoky chocolate finish. With livelier carb and a bit more creaminess to the body, this would be a classic.

Very dark mahogany.  Thick.  Some straw head.
Very clean aroma.  Some roasty notes.
Spicy carbonation, thick, sweet.
Roasty and toasty malt flavor.
AMazing interplay between smokey roastiness and smoked malt smokiness.

From a 12oz Bottle.  Pours a mostly transparent, dark brown color with a moderate head of fizzy tan.  Pleasant smokey aroma; it has a bit of an ashy, woody, campfire quality.  I hate to use the word "balanced" to describe a smoked beer, but thats really whats going on here.  Clean malt aromas of chocolate and mild toast come through in equal parts with the smoke.  The smoke is rather similar to the quality of the Alaskan Smoked Porter, but the level is a bit less.  I want more of that ham, bacon, and salty intensity.  Medium bodied, moderately carbonated mouthfeel with a soft talcum-like malt texture.  Flavors of dry chocolate and toasted bread, along with the namesake woody smoke.  Clean finish with a lingering chocolate and smokey maltiness.

Thanks to Stine for this bottle. Pours out a nice almost black with a moderate slightly off white head. Aroma is of smoked meat, wood and some earthy notes. Flavor is complex, not overly smoky but a nice woodsy smoke flavor, burnt leaves, slight chocolate and some roast. A nice lingering smoked wood aftertaste. I liked this one

Bottle from trade with Fantomas23.  Dark brown, nearly black pour with a thin tan head.  Nice rich smoky aroma over roast malts.  The smoke is not too intense or meaty.  The taste has a touch of smoke on it, but the underlying porter is nice and roasty.  Id prefer more smoke, but the base beer is well done and extremely drinkable.

Dark ruby brown color.  Smells like wood and smoke.  Tastes malty and salty.  Rich, blackened grains are most apparent, behind that comes a little smoke, fruit, and blood, but without the metallic twang.  Good, highly drinkable, and light, but maybe too light.  I cant decide.

Another bottle courtesy of drewbeerme.  Pours a deep ox blood color with a one finger foamy tan head.  Great lacing.  Nose is bacon and ham cooked over a campfire.  Palate is less smokey than I anticipated given the nose.  Hints of smoke, mild coffee, chocolate and roasted malts.  Mouth feel  is a little watery than expected, but its still a nice smoked porter.

Charcoal and bacon waft above this deeeep crimson pour with a quickly dissipating khaki head.  Nice chocolate flavor with baconlike smoke and a nice hoppiness.  Creamy mouthfeel.  Just a delicious brew. Thanks Adam!

pours deep deep brown, rich frothy tan head, slight lacing.  the aroma has a little smoke, a hint of bacon and a good measure of malty sweetness.  the flavor has more smoke than the aroma suggested, but still the sweetness seems to dominate the smoke and bacon (i would prefer the other way).  this brew is a touch sweet for me, but as the beer warmed, i warmed to it, and enjoyed sipping it while a read a book.  a comic book perhaps, but a book none-the-less.  this isnt   masterpiece theater   after all.

thanks to <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=1 cornfield for this bottle

Bottle:  Pours a dark brown with a reddish hue.  Nice creamy beige head.  Aroma is roasty malt, bits of sweetness, and faint smoke.  Taste is roasty, toffee, and light smoke.  Just a hint of chocolate.  Nice how the smoke remains a compliment rather than the entire focus.  Thanks Degarth!

Bottle: Tawny mahogany color, nice tan head and some clean lacing. The nose is roasty with some caramel and sharp burnt vanilla, some bright fruity roast that might be perceived as smoke but it doesnt fool me. The flavor is smoked though, but it doesnt come until the tail. A dry and moderate body and mouthfeel melds into a healthy sweet malt and hop tail. Nice balanced finish, good roast and smoke duo.

Dark beer with a nice tightly compacted foamy head. Flavor is smooth and more smooth. Roasted lightly smoky malts with a bit of fruitiness and some chocolate. Just a bit of dry hop at the end to clean it up. I really like the way this beer was approached, with the smoke making itself known but not becoming the primary aspect of it. Medium body. Nothing but deliciousness here.

12oz bottle, best guess is this came from Ughmash in our most recent trade.  Its been in my fridge for a while.  Shared with my girlfriend who loves smoky beers.  Pours brownish black, not quite as dark as a porter as Id expect.  Head is nice and big and tan.  Nose is smoke city, meaty, roasty and rich.  Taste evokes the same kind of smoke as in the nose, in some ways this is like drinking meat, but its beer.  Sometimes I dont know how I feel about smoked as a style.  For the style this is pretty damn good and like smoked beers Ive had recently.  Smooth on taste, smoky as hell, as good as Id expect from an unplugged beer.

Bottle. Big thanks to Stine for sending this one to me. Poured a nice black body with thin head. Aroma is chocolate, roasted malt and some smoke. Flavor is chocolate, roasted coffee, light smoke and a nice sweet maltiness to it. The smoke sstarted to come out a little stronger near the end which was quite pleasant. Smoked beers are either hit or miss for me but this one was a homerun.

Bottles from valpoaj and Stine - thanks!  Nice looking dark brown color on this guy with a light head.  Aroma has some nice meaty, smokiness with some roasty malt and chocolate.  Flavor has a subtle meaty/smokiness with a pleasant hop bite, some chocolate and coffee, and woodiness.  A really nice mix - not quite an Alaskan Smoked Porter, but a damn good representation of the style - very drinkable and went good with the Chicken my wife made.

Bottle (12oz).  Shared with tupalev, my bottle from my FestivuSanta 07!.  Opaque,oily, dark  pour, smallish slightly fizzy tan head (4-).  Warming really opened this one up - I would have been maybe 3.6 or so initially - glad I waited.  Terrific porter aroma - deep roast nutty/chocolate malt, smelled oily and rich, with molasses and dry herbal bitterness; over all of it rode strong but not overpowering hardwood/peat smokiness.  The taste followed, deep rich nutty roast and coffee, the earthy peat and herbal bitterness were more pronounced.  Reasonably thick body and quite a lively mouthfeel - had a long, astringent, near-burnt finish.  Beyond solid - terrific.

Smells better than it tastes.  A mild smoked meat aroma with some chocolate in the background.  My first impression with the taste was that it is very dry and chalky going down.  The smaller the sips the more smoke I taste otherwise it gets watery and thin.  Not one I would try again.
Poured pitch black with a tan head. Aroma - Coffee and bourbon. Quite smokey as one would expect from the name with some roast malt, coffee and a hint of cocoa. Very similiar to a scotch ale.

Big thanks to Harry for sharing this.  Black with red hues, creamy white head.  Looks nice.  Beautiful aroma - tons of smoke, sweet roast -lovely.  Nice taste - sold silky body, lots of smoke, subtle roast, nice hops mixing with smoke in finish.  A beautiful smoked porter.

Thanks to Eben for this one.  Opaque black body with a tall tan head formed that becomes frothy as it shrinks.  The aroma is roasted and chocolaty but has an incredibly pleasant bbq smoke character as well.  The flavor is almost creamy.  Its light on the palate and chocolaty.  Smoke prevails throughout but is not overpowering.  Great departure and well done.

Dark pour with a small tan head.  Aroma of light chocolate, chocolate, hickory, and smoke.  Taste is of chocolate, smoke, and a slight burntness.  Incredibly smoothpalate.  Very nice finish.  Everything seemed to have been done right with this brew.  Make it an imperial and Im hooked.  Would buy again.
Pours black with a medium tan head.  Nice clean aroma of sweet chocolate and smoke.  Taste is the same with a little bitterness in the end.  Good stuff.  Thanks Grim!!

Wow, pours a deep black with frothy tan head (dissipates quickly).  Aroma is incredibly complex smoking.  Reminds of the old fish smokehouse in Port Washington, WI just north of where I grew up.  Not overbearing, but great aroma.  Flavor contains smoke up front with a great dry malt balance.  Essences of smoke and wood and burnt caramel.  A bit of biscuit too.  Finish is clean from the dryness.  Medium body smooths everything out just perfect.  Best smoked porter I have had.  Really nice!  Thanks to Bockyhorsey for this excellent beer from the homeland!!!

12 oz. bottle either from joeybgood or secret santa, thanks to both.  Pours an extremely dark brown with mahogany highlights.  Good sized creamy beige head leaves delicate lacing.  The nose is the perfect amount of smoke along with chocolate and roasted and caramel malts.  The flavor is much like the aroma.  Nothing dominates and it works well together.  Smoke, roasted malts, caramel malts, and chocolate all in balance.  Medium bodied and creamy smooth.  I would love to have more access to this and all other NG beers.

12-oz bottle received via trade with tjthresh.  Pours opaque with a small, frothy, brown head, somewhat lasting with fair lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (toasted grain, nutty, coffee), light hops (grass), average yeast (leather, broth) with notes of smoke, prunes, and wood.  Medium bodied, creamy texture, average carbonation, and a creamy finish.  Long duration, light sweetness, acidity, and bitterness.

Bottle pours a clear black with red light getting through.  A small head was short lived and becomes a surface ring around the glass.  The aroma is smoke house, malty sweetness, caramel, coffee, and chocolate.  The flavor is roasted, sweet, lactic, coffee, chocolate, ale fruit notes, and smoke all the way through.  In fact, there is the feeling of smoke in my throat.  The palate is rich and creamy.  This one is good.  Later - I seem to be burping up smoke house meats.  I love Sconnie.

Poured a clear deep brown color with an off-white head.  Nice smoke in the front of the aroma.  Some sweet roast mixes in.  Smoky raosted malt flavor.  Nice but small let down after the smooth aroma.  Light to medium bodied and still a very nice beer.

Deep opaque and cherry color with a tannish head that remains throughout the session. Aroma mimics a small town Wisconsin (German) butcher shop combined with a campfire. Flavor is soot, chocolate and apple wood. Medium to full bodied, creamy smoky texture. Short bitter finish.

Aroma of woodsy smoke with some light toffee and caramel. The nose is certainly very subtle, but inviting nevertheless. The beer appears black with red tints and there is a sand colored one finger head. The sweet malt, nuttiness, and cream is the first thing you taste before the smoke saunters in. The smoke is the dominant flavor, though it never seems hammy, artificial, or overpowering, some of the things than can take away from other examples of the style, at least fresh ones. The sweet maltiness and roast in the underlying porter really help the beer shine. This really is one of the most rounded smoked beers, porter or otherwise, that I have had. The New Glarus Unplugged series seem to be one winner after the next. Well done!

12 oz. bottle - Poured blackish brown with beige head. Aroma is quite smokey with some coffee and chocolate notes. Nice creamy beer with well balanced chocolate malt flavor leaving you with a dry slightly smokey finish. A good brew bot not something I could drink evry day.

Bottled. Nice black center with some very dark brown edges and a light beige film capping the surface. Light lacing eventually settles down to some white spots on the glass edges. Aroma is a thick and pleasant barbecue smoke with a touch of fresh cut wood notes and chocolate malts hiding behind everything. Really nice flavor that starts with a strong smoke statement with a touch of saltiness that re-creates the nose of a true meat smokehouse! Nice! Dark chocolates are found throughout with robust black malts. Medium bodied with a carbonated sting in the finish, slight bitterness lingers, but the smoked notes fade rather quickly. Intriguing!

Black with a thick, creamy long lasting chocolate head.
Light aroma of smoke, roasted malts and chocolate.
Flavor is roasted malts and chocolate.
Thin creamy body with a nice smoked finish.
Good beer.

12 oz bottle.  Poured a dark, nearly opaque brown.  When held up to the light one can see a bit of deep amber, but thats it.  Its easy to see this is a full-bodied brew.  A bit of a tan head stuck around.  Smoked, malty aroma, very mild.  But the flavor, wow.  Smoked flavor really cut through, but it gave way quickly to a sustained malt taste with delicious chocolate notes.  Again, this is a full-bodied beer, and one can definitely feel it.  I was a bit disappointed that the smoke flavor didnt linger, but some may enjoy its nuanced character.  Overall a great porter.

Very nice, but this wants to be a Porter much more than it wants to be a Rauchbier, and my preference is for the latter.  Nice pour, a nearly black dark brown body with a substantial beige head that coats the glass with spidery Belgian lacing. This beer is so good, I wanna dip my... Seriously, this is my first 5 point brew. Thanks to badbeer. Pours deep, dark brown color with a somewhat thin but resilient off-white head. Head is somewhat sticky and leaves a bit of lace down the glass. I could smell the smoke as I opened it on the counter. Thats about all that I get is smokey with a faint maltiness. Awesome. The taste is the best part. This beer explodes with flavor as it crosses my lips. Lots of smoke and super toasty malts abound on this one. The mouthfeel is the second best part, the carbonation is vibrant and active. It helps to move the flavors around my mouth. This beer is full bodied too, more than any other porter Ive ever had. More on the way and I cant wait.

Thanks to Ughsmash for this brew. Delicious smoked porter. Pours very dark brown, bordering on black, with a soft khaki head. Roasty chocolate nose with a woody smoked backbone. Smooth on the palate with a smoked character that doesnt jump out at you and take over, more sits back and compliments the soft sweetness.

Courtesy of gillard. Poured dark brown with tan head. The aroma hits you with a pulse of smoke and wood before faint roasty malts are noticed behind the smoke. The taste begins with nice smokiness that leads into bacon wrapped wood. Theres also faint roasty malts hidden somewhat by the smoke. So the base beer is a bit lost. I do enjoy the level of smokiness here. It seems to be in the middle of a Aecht Schlenkerla Urbock and Alaskan Smoked Porter for smoke strength with the Urbock being the beast of smoked brews.
12 oz bottle; Nose of chocolate, smoke, and vanilla; black with a medium beige head; flavor of smoke and chcolate.

Pours a very dark brown with a slightly smallish head. Aroma of smoked meat, chocolate, and a bit of coffee. Nice mouthfeel, smooth and easy to drink. Solid beer in a style that Im not really all that crazy about.

thanks to Pantanap for letting me try this one.  Poured a translucent dark brown into the snifter.  Smell was bacon, smoked malt and some background chocolate.  Taste was nice and smooth, like a full breakfast in a bottle, smoke came through nicely and rounded out the chocolate, dark roasty character and distant hop bite.  One of the best smoked beers I have had.

Good smoke aroma and flavor, but not as full as something out of Bamberg.  Very little carbonation, some lactose, wood, and medium sweet malt.  Smoke throughout, but I would like more smoke aroma and flavor.

Poured from a 12oz bottle and served in an English pint glass.  This porter poured a dark brown with a large, slowly fading head of dark tan foam.  A decent amount of lacing was left around the glass.  The aroma of the beer was made up of bittersweet chocolate, charred malts, and moderate smoke.  The flavor consisted of mocha, vanilla, burnt wood, smoke, cold coffee, and a mild bready yeast note.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied with light carbonation.  A nicely done porter, but I would have prefered the smokiness to be a bit more aggressive.

Courtesy hopscotch. This one poured a really dark brown almost black color with a thin white head that left behind small amounts of lacing. This has a very nice smokey aroma of a campfire with some smoked meat and sausage being cooked. The flavor is very roasty and smokey as well. It isnt too smokey though to where it is not enjoyable though. Flavors of smoked sausage, smoked malts, and dark chocolate all come through. The mouthfeel is creamy and medium bodied with low carbonation that has a nice roasty and smokey finish to it. This one is really easy to drink, and a nicely done smoked beer. I really enjoyed this one.

pours dark ruby with a thin off white head.  Massive smoke going on in this one.  Aroma of malts and campfire.  Flavor has burnt chocolate,  campfire,  roasted malts,  and apple.  Finishes oily and just a little too thin.  A very example of how to make a good version of this style.

(Bottle) Pours a dark brown color with a off-white head. Aroma of smoked sausage, and roasted malt. Flavor is very smoky up front, with some dark chocolate, vanilla, dusty malts, and toffee. Creamy mouthfeel. Low carbonation, and high drinkability. Another great beer from New Glarus!

Bottle from Ughsmash. He threw this one in as a bonus! Pours almost black with a big tan head and fantastic lacing. Aroma of apple wood smoked bacon accompanied by dark roasty malts and some sweet chocolate too. Smokey campfire wood and a solid roast mesh to form pleasant flavor profile. A bit of sweeter roast peaks through in the back end too. Lots of lingering dry roast and salty smoke. Smooth carbonation. I really like this one. I really enjoy smoked porters though, so I might be a bit biased. The only complaint is that it might be a tad thin but that is really not a huge issue.

About a 1 inch head of fine and dense bubbles.  Settles slowly.  Smokey aroma with some sweet malts, smoldering wood and some soy sauce.  Color is a very dark brown.  Wow, big smoky flavor.  Very BIG!  Some ash and carbon flavors with some dark roasted malts, coffee and a bit of caramel.  Much more smoke in the flavor than in the aroma.  Finishes sweet and malty with a lingering ashy smoke flavor.  This is a VERY smoky beer.  A little bit to much for me.

Black pour with a still, thin, contemplative, tan head. Excellent, rich, woody, sweet smoky campfire aroma. Strong, lean, sinewy  smoke flavor. Rather light in body with a quick finish. Has some strange saccharine notes. Starts great but doesnt quite follow through. The body and dark malts could be punched up. The smoke flavor is very nice.

Bottle from the Ugh.  Great appearance as spotty lace stuck all over the top of the glass.  Seductive aroma - lures you in with roasted chocolate malt and a hint of rich vanilla.  First impression at a fairly warm temp was not all that great.  This rarely happens for me - but considering the thin body - this thing had to go back in the fridge.  Much more enjoyable at a colder temp.  The body turned a bit more full and the flavor rounded out.  Core of solid porter flavors - but I really enjoyed the sweeter smoky flavor on the finish.  Wish it was a bit thicker in body.  Nice!

Thanks to pantanap for this one. 

Lightly smoked aroma and flavor, dark brown body with a tiny bubbled dirty heead, this is a fairly light bodied brew.
Sweet chocolatey aroma, some slightly acrid smoke. Smoke flavor is light, coming through as salty smoked bacon. Heavy roast and dark chocolate. Creamy palate.
Black pour w/ off-white head.  Smoke and hops on the nose.  Big smoke taste followed up by chocolate.  Thin mouthfeel.  Courtesy of Enzofan.
Shared by toncatcher at the Red Poppy release. Nice flavors of wood, and some coffee.

12 oz bottle shared with toncatcher.  Smokey aromas and flavors.  Some chocolate and porter dustiness as well.  Alcohol was well hidden.  I didnt think the smoke was over the top at all.  I have had much smokier beers.  This was pretty good.

Tried at the Lost Abbey Line tasting.  Kind of eager to try this, because of the high rating, but at the same time Im not a big fan of smoked porters.  Was offered this in a trade one time, but I turned it down. Some smoke in the aroma.  Brown color.  Dry.  Some bonus points for being interesting with the smoke aroma.
The smoke was just too overpowering. Had the taste and feel of burnt bacon. The appearance was nice, good head but the smell should have been the give away.

Foam Rangers January meeting. Dark, dark brown with rich mocha head. Aroma is smoked malts, chocolate and smoke itself. Flavor is very smokey with some chocolate and wood flavors. The malt makes this balanced and the finish is nice and roasty.

Acquired in a trade from Stine.  Very dark brown in color with a medium tan head.  Aroma: chocolate, smoked meat, light roast.  Smoke is assertive for the style.  Taste is roasty- with chocolate, caramel and alot of smoked meats/wood.  The sweet molasses and roast balance the smoke nicely.  The body is medium- finishes with lingering roast bitterness as well as smoke.  Really good. Thanks Eben!

A creamy tan head sits on top of a very dark, almost opaque color, with just a hint of a dark red hue in the base of the glass. Aroma is of chocolate, hickory smoke, licorice. The texture on the tongue is creamy, smooth and nicely carbonated. Taste is of carmel, smoke but not overly smokey, with the dark roasted malts predominating. It makes an excellent accompaniment to a bowl of chili on a cold Wisconsin day.

Bottle purchased at Discount, Milwaukee, into shaker.  Pours with a large creamy head that turns fluffy and rocky with firm surface.  Chunky, sticky and loose lacing.  Meaty, fruity smokiness in the aroma.  Strong smoke on the outskirts of the flavor, summer sausage and smooth semi-sweet chocolate in the middle.  Tasty.  Finish coats the mouth.  One of the better Unpluggeds Ive had in a while; I think its rating is right on point.  That being said, I usually dont like smoked beers.

Thanks to Ughsmash and tytoanderso, who both sent me a bottle of this one. Pours dark brown with a large head. Good retention. Aroma is smoke, chocolate, dark roasted malt and attic dust. Medium body. Finishes dry and dusty.

Bottle.   Pours inky black color with a thinnish brown colored head.   Aroma is smoke, caramel, chocolate.   Flavor is smokey, caramel, choclate, oak.   Palate is full bodied, medium carbonation, finished on the sweet side.   One  of the better smoked beers Ive had.

12oz bottle.  Pours a deep, dark mahogany with a healthy mocha-colored head.  Aroma is both smoky and sweet, with the unmistakable aroma of smoked wood along with hints of caramel, apples, and spices.  Taste is creamy and medium-bodied, with a strong smoky almost bacon-like flavor giving way to a long stout-like finish of chocolate, vanilla, molasses, and coffee.  Really unique flavors here, though only for those with true grit and guts.

Dense and impossibly dark with a light and earthy aroma. The actual flavor is incredible: notes of smoked cedar, oak, and pine all come through with amazing clarity and a meaty, toasted malt finish that disappears as quickly as it came.
Enjoy this particularly robust beer along with grilled balsamic duck or onion-roasted potatoes.

Dark brown with a creamy beige head.  Aroma is sweet, smoky, spicy malt.  Tastes of dark chocolate, sweet malt and sweet smoke.  Smooth and medium bodied with a nice creamy feel to it.  Another hit for the unplugged series.

12 oz bottle.  Dark brown with a thin tan head.  Nose is grapes and brown sugar with growing smoke.  Medium light body.  Taste is coffee and spritzy unsweetened Concord with burnt grass smoke.  Ferric lime peel in the finish.  Seems a bit young.

355 ml bottle from a trade with Ughsmash. pours dark brown with red edges and a medium tan head that lingers all the way through. aromas are a bit smokey with ripe apple and sweet malt coming through. the smoke accents the aromas more then it is the aroma and is in no way over bearing. flavours are an awesome blend of smoke, ripe fruit, coffee, and other malty sweetness. suffers from being a touch to thin but still amazing. thanks Ughsmash!

its tasty....its tasty. smokey good roots here. Let it warm before drinking as the aromas and flavors really flourish. smells of smoked venison and bacon. very good a bit watery mouthfeel but thats its only downfall solid beer for sure!

Pours extremely dark mahogany to virtually black in color.  A medium sized, foamy tan head settles quickly to a thin blanket.  Solid rings of lacing circle the glass, breaking up into amoeba like organic splotches over time.  The aroma is very malty and smoky.  Roasted barley and dark chocolate malts show in the foreground, while charred oak and hints of coffee follow closely behind.  The flavor showed a bit more of a subdued smokiness, with coffee taking a more prominent role.  Some oaky vanilla and cream add smoothness, while a touch of cola adds some caramel or molasses sweetness. The mouthfeel is substantial, but its a touch over carbonated and chalky for my liking.  Solid brew, for sure, but it doesnt quite live up to the incredibly high standard that previous Unpluggeds have set.

Explosive smoked nose dominates a porter-black pour with a brief tan head. Palate is nicely smooth and indicates a medium body despite the robust flavors.  The flavors are much more of the smoked qualities before a rounding-out with roast, coffee, and a brief sweetness.  The flavors balance excellently and smoke plays a great role as a tweak on an otherwise sweet porter. Another creative, solid New Glarus brew.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2008 12 oz bottle pours a dark brown black with a brown head.  When I first pour it the nose is very smoky - campfire and meat.  But it quickly dissipates with chocolate, roasted malts and the meat/smoke in the background.  Creamy mouthfeel but a little light bodied.  Burnt malt flavors, chocolate, roast, earthy wood, campfire and smoked ham.  Earthy drying malt finish.  Flavors are a little light, but a nicely done smoked.  I can drink this beer often.  So interesting and fun to drink.

Thanks to ogglethorp for the trade. Pours a deep brown with lots of amber notes and an average bubbly/creamy tan lacing head.  Aroma of smoked meats, roasted malts, some dark chocolate notes, woody/earthy and a touch of some caramel. Flavor of campfire smoke, coffee grinds...as the flavor lingers on my tongue I get some milk chocolate and a touch of vanilla.

Yet again, thanks for sharing yjb!  This is what a beer should look like, period.  Dark dark brown with a thin tan head.  Bacon at first, but chcooalte comes out more and more.  A bit of sweet oaky(?) tannins in with the sweet sweet malt.  The nose changes dramatically with the temperature.  Perfect mouth.  Creamyy, but small bubbles.  Not heavy on the palate, but full and creamy.  Ethereal.  Nice flavor, but short of the nose.  big bacony smoke.  Yummy chocolatey porter with significant roast.  hops of the floral sort.  Bitter aftertaste acidic surprising.  Warming hurt this beer a bit, drink her fast!
MMmmm Bacon wood and porter. Smells good tastes better, a very enjoyable beer!

12 oz botlte, left my someone the night after YEhA 07 in our hotel room.  I drank this the next morning (hungover as hell) and took some notes.  Pours a woody brown almost black, with a thin lasting head.  Aroma is surprisingly more smokey than anticipated- lots of campfire smoke, woody , nutty, and good chocolate aromas.  Nice warming nutty and toasty malt flavors, good smoked meats and wood.  Smooth cold smoke finish.  Nice smoked porter!  Not as harsh or burny as the Alaskan, about as good maybe.

12 ounce bottle from Ughsmash.  Pours basicly opaque dark brown.  There are the slightest bit of red hues.  Small tan head.  The smoke character is light, but pleasing.  Certainly a bit bacon-ish.  A fair amount of chocolate character as well.  Fantastic balance between the smoke and chocolate flavors.  Medium body.  Silky.  Medium carbonation.  Dry finish.  A fine beer.
Poured dark brown with a khaki head.A nice smoke on the nose.Roastedness and smoke on the flavor with a nice smooth finish

bottle....poured medium bodied and  almost black in nature.  what started as a fluffy tan head quickly vanished but left a creamy film on the top....aroma had an abundance of chocolate and roasted malt and wasnt too overwhelmed by the smokiness.  in fact, the smoke and char played a subsidiary role.....flavors piggy-backed off of the aromas even more.  what i admired about this smoked was the creamy mouthfeel and how little carbonation there was and the just right level of sweetness from the malt.....im not a huge smoked fan but this has been my favorite of the ones ive tried.  well done new glarus!

Bottle from sliffy.  Thanks!  Pours a dark brown cola color with a nice sized tan head that fades a bit. Good flavors of char, roasted malts, chocolate, some wood, and light smokiness.  Nose is roasty with a bit of wood and smoke. Very nice easy drinking smoked beer. I dont like my beer to smokey so this one was just right.  Another great one from the Dan. Mr. Carey AND Sliffy!
Nice tan head. Theres a smoky aroma for sure but not too much. Body is smooth as hell with the destinct flavor of Shlenkerla malts. Bacon-y and ham-my. Quite possibly as good as AK.

Poured a dark brown color with a small, tan head that left nice lacing on the glass. Aroma of light smoke, chocolate, roasted malts, and apple wood. Taste of cocoa, roast, applewood, smoke, and a dry finish.

Bottle... This beer rocks!... Clear, almost black beer with a small, creamy, khaki head. When held up to very bright light, a crimson halo appears around the edges of my glass. Simply a chocolate and smoked meat aroma. Sweet, smoky flavor doesnt become cloying, but tiptoes around it. Nice bitterness, but theres not enough of it. Medium-bodied and lightly creamy with pillow-soft carbonation. Lengthy, smoky-sweet, and then minerally, bitter finish. Kudos to pepsican for shipping the bottle my way!
Finally an unplugged with no cherries!!  Pours dark brown with tan head.  Light smoked malt flavor, roasted malts and milk chocolate.  Typical porter flavor with a bit of smoke... add more smoke.

Courtesy hopscotch.  Pours dark brown, with almost no head whatsoever.  Smells of a good amount of smoke, that typical campfire/Sunday morning breakfast aroma that is so pleasant.  Not a total smoke bomb, but certainly prevalent.  The flavor definitely seemed alot more smoky than the nose.  Alot of fire and bacon, with some syrupy malts and tiny hints of chocolate were also detected.  Pretty nice smoked beer.  Well done.

12 oz. bottle via trade with Ughsmash - Pours a dark brown color with a one and a quarter finger thick light tan head.  Nice lacing.  Aroma is mostly smoked malt.  Flavor is smoked and light roasted malt and hints of chocolate.  Palate is a touch thin and dry.  The smokiness seems to linger.  The beer is somewhat one dimensional, but good none the less.  Thanks Jason.

Pours a deep brown, with a 1 tan, foamy head. Nice lacing. Very smoky aroma, with subtle malts. Tastes like Im eating the BBQ, subtle coffee notes. A little dry aftertaste. Light bodied porter. Not a bad beer, but the smoke is a little overbearing.
user_location: Mescal Lakes (wherever that is), Arizona, USA

text: Pours an almost black but actually very dark brown shade with ruby highlights along the edge of the glass when held to the light. Smoke (bacony) is the first and most prominent scent but this is a porter and some coffee like roastiness. The flavor absolutely rocks my world with hints of the aforementioned smoked bacon, cock hardening chocolate, and fist pumping coffee. This beer is truly wonderful.

Bottle: Pours a rich dark mahogany color with a big frothy tan head. Aroma of hickory smoked bacon, roasted malts and light coffee. Has medium body to it with the flavors of smoked bacon, roasted coffee and dark chocolate. Has a rather complex array of flavors of hops and malts inter-twined. Has a dry, slightly bitter finish. Nice all around well crafted brew.

Bottle from iowaherkeye (thanks!).  Pours dark brown with a decent bit of head.  Aroma was slightly smoky along with roasted malts.  Taste was better, with a nice roasty taste complimented well by some smoke.  Palate was thick and full.  Im a fan.

The latest in NGs Unplugged series is deepest brown/black with no light visible through the glass. There is a full, thick light brown head. The aroma is definitely smoky beef jerky with roasted sweet malts in the background. The flavor is very roasty with a pleasant smoked wood note. Really smooth and delicious. If you like porters, this is a great one to try for a new spin on an old favorite. Dan Carey is one imaginative dude. Great!

12oz Bottle, thanks to Drewbeerme for bringing some back for me.  Dark brown to opaque black in complexion with medium darktan head.  Aroma is very smokey, chocolate, some vanilla, very nice.  Smoke, medium sweet flavor that comes off as being fruity, chocolate, vanilla, light hop bitterness, meaty.  Full body and creamy.  Very nice.
Pours black with a moderate, tan head. Aroma is smoked. The mouth feel is moderate with a strong smoky flavor and a mildly sweet backing.

Pours a dark copper/brown color with a fair amount of light-colored head. Aroma is a very meaty smoked notes. Flavors are smoked pork with hints of carmelized brown sugar. The smoke and sugar flavors balance eachother out. It isnt a thick beer by any means but flavor is rich. All around an okay porter.

Date: 12/18/2007
Mode: Bottle
Source: Trade

opaque dark brown, fine tan head, lots of drippy lace, 
smoked bacon and chocolate aroma, 
rich dark chocolate flavor, lots of smoked character, touch of sweetness from dark caramel malts, light earthy hops balance the caramel sweetness and meld with the smokeyness, light lingering bitter finish rises out of the smoke and dark bitter chocolate, 

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20
Rating: 3.3/5.0Drinkability: 7/10

12 oz Bottle. Nice glazed brown sugar and pork shoulder smoke, nips of bacon on chocolate and barbeque. Rubied mahogany pour with rim of soft tan. Great soft smoke through a some caramels, generic darker sugars and sweet malt. The smoke is a real nice soft fruity character that plays evenly with a straightforward malt body. Tastes filtered from the get-go, and Im right. Theres some green woodiness, but its not detracting. This is a good beer; soft and quiet, but it could be so much better if it hadnt been filtered. Finishes on a good gummy hop smack. Good body balance, though. Thanks for sharing everything Sean!

Bottle and served in my NB worthy glass: A deep brown hue with coppery highlights topped by a fading frothy tan head which left spotty lace. The aroma has notes of smoked meat and smoked wood, hints of coffee, chocolate, herbal hops, and a touch of fig. The taste mostly follows suit with a dry smoky wood character upfront supported by some ripened fleshy fruit, chocolate and walnut. The finish shows some coffee and perhaps some hop bitterness. The mouth feel is lively and thin (yep it is a porter) with a dry chalky finish. Overall a solid solid porter where the smoke is forward but does not cover up the malt completely. A bit more chocolate or sweet malt and this would have rocked. Worthy of a try.
Dark beown color with no head. Lite smoky notes. Taste was of dark roasted malt and light smoke. Dry light bitter finish.
Meaty, smokey. Chocalate and coffee notes are downplayed. Similar to arcadias port but better. Nice lingering aftertaste.

12 oz bottle. Thanks to Joey (iowaherkeye) for bringing this one back from Madison. Poured a nearly opaque black color with orange highlights. Head was thick and light brown with a peach colored tint. It reduced over a few minutes to a thin film. Some lace was left behind at the end. Aroma was of chocolate with a whiff of coffee. There was only the slightest hint of smoke/barbeque in the nose. Smelled like most porters. Mouth feel was smooth and creamy with delicate sweetness on the tongue. Mmmm, very velvety. Carbonation was on the low end of the spectrum. Tasted mostly of chocolate and coffee. The coffee was most noticeable toward the end and was accompanied by very mild roasty bitterness. As predicted by my nose, the smoke flavor was fairly subtle. Almost a tease, really. Good beer.
Very nice for me. My type of smoke. Not too heavy on the smoke and had a lot of flavor otherwise with some molasses and cream. Very faint spices too round it out.

Bottle courtesy of ughsmash.  Pours dark brown (almost black) with a thin dissipating light brown head.  Smells of pronounced smoke, chocolate, touches of honey and caramel.  Tastes slightly tarte with a nice underlying smokiness, lots of spices, thick layered dark malt, hints of coffee and a touch of bitterness.  Mouthfeel is full and textured.  Finish reveals hints of burnt molasses.  Wow!

Dark chocolate brown color with a thick head.  I made a conscious decision to not read the description on the label before drinking this.  That said, the aroma was very much like a beechwood smoke.  Apple wood must be fairly similar in aroma and taste.  Lightly roasted malt is also present in the aroma.  The taste is definitely smoky, but not completely overpowering.  Plenty of chocolate and dry malts.  Finishes dry and a little earthy.  Not out of this world, but very solid and tasty.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of a trade with ogglethorp.  Pours nearly black with a dense, creamy, long-lasting, beige colored head that coated the glass nicely.  Very pleasant aroma of light smoke along with a bit of malt and coffee.  The flavor is quite nice with gentle smokiness along with a bit of malt and coffee.  The smoke flavor, although mild, lingers on the palate well beyond the swallow.  Very enjoyable brew.

Poured a deep, rich black, with some glints of brown.  Aroma is subtley smokey, with the roast component dominanting this dance.  Hints of coffee and a slight dark fruit charecter.  Flavor is mild, with virtually none of the smoke making an apperance.   The slight tang on the finish is interesting.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2007 Fat bubbles glaze a khaki head that quickly (only partially)recedes to reveal an oily appearing brown body that leans towards chestnut. The aroma is heavily and pleasantly smoky, a complex array of smoking meats and burning malts. Hints of molasses, chocolate, brown sugar and roasted grains all creep out. The nose is sweet and firm. The flavor is milder and more astringent than expected. Sweetness is medium, smokiness medium-high and without any annoying acridity. nutty malts and chocolate play off of each other well, with coffee and light hops rounding things out and adding a soft bitterness. The mouthfeel is barely medium bodied, somewhat smooth and fun. Carbonation is average. Pretty interesting but not the amazing creation I had hoped the latest from New Glarus would be. Cant win em all.
12oz bottle. Poured a deep and dark brown color with an off white head. Aromas of roast, chocolate, toffee and smoke (not over powering). Tastes of chocoalte, smoke roast, vanilla, and coffee.
Bottle shared by MaxxDaddy. Nice smoky aroma, a little thin, but the flavor is nice and rich, great porter flavors with a thick, delicious body. Really really tasty. Need more!
This was a very good smooth and tastey beer with hints of smoke flavor but not overwhelming like most smoked beers,I was surprised to get this and it was very enjoyable.CHEERS!

Very good.  From the bottle, courtesy of Mrs. ProsQtor -- who had to listen to a litany of gripes about the day, and then provided this unexpected lift.  Among the best Porters Ive tasted.  Perfect for a snowy night.

Good stuff.  Decent amount of roast and a light amount of smoke and char in the nose.  Not a smoke bomb, but it works well, the porter is still alive.  Mildly frothy, with a starchy potato or bread flavor, finishing with almost a sour smoke note.  I like it.  Thanks CaptainCougar for the bottle!

UPDATED: DEC 14, 2007 Thanks to iowaherkeye for the bottle. Black body with a light khaki head. The smoke aroma has some notes of camp fire with some toffee. The taste is relatively subtle with the smoke and some light baked potato.There is a little bit of roasted coffee, but it is very subtle. A nicely made porter with a mild smoke character. Another winner from New Glarus.

12/13/07, 12oz bottle. recently released. pours dark brown with creamy tan head. nose of smoked meats and chocolate. flavor is smokey beets, milk chocolate, mild roast, and a caramel finish. very smooth and clean finish. body is medium. very drinkable. carbonation is really nice and smooth. IMO, this should be classified as a porter not a smoked, the smoke is big in the aroma but only hints in the flavor as it has a clearly more porter taste to it. a darn fine porter though. this is very drinkable and tasty, perfect for the winter season when you want something complex, drinkable, and warming at the same time. I could see re-rating this higher in the future.

12oz bottle courtesy of Skyview. Aroma of smoked wood and chocolate. Wife served me this brew in the New Glarus pint glass she brought back on recent trip to Wi. Black bocdy with decent head. Creamy chocolate flavor along with some cola carbination. Mild dry coco lingers on palate. Smooth and enjoyable brew. Thanks Bob.

On tap at Horse & Plow
Pours a still deep brown with a nice tan head with hints of red. The head settles nicely and retains for longer than I cared to wait! The aroma was a bit overwhelming at first. Almost like opening a bottle of liquid smoke at first, but mellows out nicely to reveal a Carmel-dark fruit base. The flavor is a wallop of smoke followed by sweetness followed by a nice hop finish. It almost has too much smokiness for me. Surprisingly, a very light beer. Much lighter than I expected at 9.5%. Laying this down for a while should do wonders. VERY good!

Bottle.  Pour is dark brown with a thin, silky light brown head.  Aroma is chocolate, coffee and a some smoke, not overpowering and a hint of alcohol.  Taste of smoke, coffee and some leather, with the slightest hint of fruit.  Medium body, not heavy feeling at all.  Finish is dry.  Good stuff.

12 oz bottle
Thanks to Ughsmash for sending some of these my way.  It is one of the things Ill miss most about Wisconsin (though the selection here almost makes up for the lack of readily available New Glarus).  Ive been eagerly anticipating this one for a while to see how it would stack up against the Smoked Rye Bock.  As it turns out I think the two may be roughly equal.  The smoke does different things to each but the end result is the same - a solid one-off bottling.
Aroma / Appearance - The best part of this beer is the aroma.  I could have spent hours soaking in the smoked chestnut, coffee and fireplace scents.  It has more smoke to it than the Rye Bock but is not overpowering.  Dark fruity undertones tease at what could be inside as with most of the Unplugged series.  The pour resulted in a dark brown body with clear lacing and sandy head.
Flavor / Palate - The mouthfeel was perfectly balanced.  Not too thick and not too thin, I was able to pick up ash, cocoa and burnt marshmellows.  Blackberries and cherries unfolded next.  The finish of smoked ham reminded me of the Back Road Christmas Porter from a few years ago.  For the time of year this is the perfect beer.  The smell of a yule log burning in the fireplace would complement it well.

Opaque and cherry black in the glass with a tan wrung hugging the edges. Aroma rides the smoked hide and branded leather with lovely complexity. Fire scores the dark chocolate lingering by the hazelnuts for a symphonic smore and match made in smoked heaven. Flavor aligns more lightly than the deep delving nose had indicated, annunciated by heavy carbonation and a lacquered based body. Singed graham crackers and soot mingle with mocha grinds and apple wood to create the dark chocolate composure avec dry smoky accents. Bakers chocolate gets charred as the tongue lightly licks branded leather. The body maintains a medium balance while the substance remains mainstream, echoing with smoky dark chocolate for a lovely flavored finish to establish a worthwhile endgame.

Brown, white fizzy head.  Peat smoke nose sits on light chocolate and coffee tones.  Woodsy smoked flavor mingles with further milk chocolate and bitter coffee-like notes.  Light to medium bodied, medium carbonation, dry smoke finish.  Wish I had more.  Thanks for sharing, Ken!

Bottle from Hezron. Clear, light brown body with a small tan head. Rich smoky nose with cola, cherry and brown sugar. The flavor is lightly sweet with toffee and lots of mild smoke (apparently apple wood). Medium body is soft, but slightly thin with light carbonation. Nice, but would be greatly improved with less filtering.

Bottle trade from shigadeyo. Poured a clear black color with an average frothy brown head that mostly lasted with good lacing. Moderate roasted smoke malt aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture. Medium roasted coffee flavor with a medium bittersweet smoke finish of moderate duration. Good complex smoke brew.

(12oz bottle, thanks kmweaver) Tan head atop clear mahogany body.  Aroma is medium sweet, milk chocolate, smoke.  Taste is medium sweet, milk chocolate, smoke, light caramel, alcohol.  Smooth medium body.

Bottle. First off, let me say this: I am not a huge fan of smoked or porters, much less smoked porters. Lightly smoky aroma. Some coffee, wood and dark cookie notes. Pours dark, dark brown. Not viscous or oily. Just a light hint of smoked wood on the palate. Lots of dry roasted malt. Medium bodied. Finishes with a hint of smoky tartness. I will revisit in a few months for sure.

I agree that this beer is pretty good; and a fine example of this "Unplugged" series, which has been a bit hit&miss to me.  This beer is smoke-y and a nice sampling of summer sausage flavor Ive found in other smoked beers without the challenging intensity that some of those beers offer.  Quite nice.

This beer pours a non-viscous but rich black that is nearly opaque.  Head was rich and composed of tiny off-white bubbles.  Intially, I had maybe 2cm of it atop my pint glass although this faded to 5mm coating that covers the breadth of my beer (rim to rim coverage on the glass).  Aroma is a bit smokey, and offers some summer-sausage aroma that Ive found in other beers, like Schlenkerla, although this beers smokiness is not overpowering in its intensity.  The smokiness is up-front in this beers flavor; I get a lot of the smoked-sausage taste right at the beginning and in the front of my mouth.  At the finish the dark roastiness becomes evident.  I think this beer would be pretty good without the smokiness; I dont get the impression that the smokiness is covering up anything unpleasant.  Mouthfeel is very dry and cinder-y.  This beer is very drinkable for a smoked beer (without being boring)...most beers of this style are more challenging for me to drink than this particular example.

I would highly recommend this beer, even if youve not enjoyed other smoked beers.  I picked up a 12oz single of this at 3 Cellars in Franklin, WI.

Nice and complex aromas of fruity apple, coffee, smoke, etc... The levels of aromatics are pretty high.    Very dark brown in color, almost black with a rocky off-white head that sticks around and nice lacing.  Flavors of roasted coffee, dried cherries, dark chocolate and a nice touch of smoke in the roasty finish.  Velvety texure, low carbonation and medium body with a lighter finish.  This is very well made and enjoyable, it should have been a seasonal, not an unplugged!

Bottle thanks to Ughsmash: Pours a deep brown with a creamy tan head that left some nice lacing. Aroma, smoky notes, roasted coffee, chocolate and some bitter notes. Flavor, roasted malts, smoke, chocolate and coffee, very tasty.

11/27/2007:  Smoke on the Porter is dark brown in color, clear, and has a small foamy tan head that slowly fades.  The aroma has a nice amount of smoke that is subtly meaty and accompanied by roasted malts, semi-sweet chocolate, and black, espresso roast coffee.  Lots of rich, smooth  chocolate (semi-sweet and dark) graces the tastebuds at first.  There is also a nice, balanced level of residual sweetness.  The maltiness is then followed by a perfectly balanced and well-intergrated smoke that really isnt meaty or burnt, but something in the middle like caramelized marshmallow with some char.  The finish tastes something like milk chocolate covered smoked expresso beans followed by really, really dark chocolate.  It is really quite delicious.  The body of this beer is medium-full and it has a smooth and slightly creamy mouthfeel (probably due to the lighter than usual carbonation level).  I really like this beer, but the smoke is so subtle at times that it would be quite easy to miss it altogether (my wife didnt pick up on it at all).  Regardless, this is a great beer even if I prefer more smoke...  
12 oz bottle purchased at the New Glarus Brewing Company in New Glarus, Wisconsin.  Rating #23 for this beer...

Pours pretty much black with a medium tan head. Aroma is like a couple of other people said... smoked meats. Also light coffee, wood, malts. Flavor is a nice blend of smokey malts, light cocoa and hints of molasses. Slight tartness as well. The body is a tad thin and that is the only real knock I have for this one. Overall very good.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2008 Mmm, this was a blast of smokey goodness. Really needs to be enjoyed at close to room temp, as i detected very little smokieness when cold. Dark and roasty, with enough smoke aroma and flavor, but not overpowering. Actually would like to see more smoke flavor in there. Awfully thin on the ol pallate, surprising, but still a great brew.BEST SMOKED BEER-hands down.

Picked up four pack at Bob McFarland Liquors in McFarland, Wisconsin. Pours an opaque dark brown brew with a decent light tan head that has some good retention and spotty lacing. Aroma of a good balance of dark roasted malts, smoked citrus wood, some character of smoked ham, coffee and dark chocolate. Taste is smooth, creamy, medium to full bodied, some light carbonation with flavors of smoked dark malt, chocolate and earth spice. Finish has a slight tart and smoked malt aftertaste with a dry lingering bitterness. Not as tart as other "unplugged" series brews but this is another fine crafted specialty brew.

Strong coffee and cream aroma.  Almost black in color with a medium tan head.  Thin palate--even for a porter.  Coffee dominates the flavor with some roasted nuts and a slightly tangy aftertaste.  Dont really get much smoke for a smoke brew--thats for sure.

Enjoyed at Thanksgiving with smoked ham. Its similar to Stone Smoked Porter in that the emphasis here is more on the porter and less on the smoke. The most noticeable aspect was its creaminess, something akin to a good oatmeal stout. On the palate are soft undertones of smoke blended with coffee and cocoa powder, with a brown sugar sweetness and a solid finish. Well crafted, although certainly not exceptional.  Another fine beer by New Glarus. Thanks to Nathan for transporting this south

Bottle: Pours a semi-transparent dark mahogany with a frothy, wispy-lacing light tan head.  Aroma has some nice earthy, dry smoky notes and roasted maltiness.  Body starts lightly sweet and smoky with some roasty coffee notes and dark chocolate malts.  Nicely-balanced and quite drinkable while maintaining pleasant complexity throughout.

Courtesy of Ughsmash! Pours a dark brown colour with a small creamy tan head. Nose begins with a heavy deep set of smoke, but more ash notes than anything and roasted malts. Initial taste begins with light to medium body and mild carbonation that soakes the mouth with a roasted malts and smoke. Mild dark chocolate and burnt wood chips are the next to make their appearance. A touch of sourness in the background. Finishing with a roasted malts and smoke with a mild bitter hop. Dry Finish. Slight head retention and lacing of the glass. Very drinkable.

Bottle shared by sliffy. Brown/black pour with a tan head. Aroma of sweet smoke, roasted malt, coffee, and dark chocolate. Flavors of smoky roasted malt, subtle coffee, and dark chocolate. Medium body, roasty/smoky with a sweet/smoky finish. One easy drinking smoked, thats for sure.

12oz bottle-A black body with a nice tan head and an aroma of smoke and cooked bacon. Begins with a medium bodied beer with smoke and malt flavors with more smoke kicking in on the back end. I think fairly light for a Porter but otherwise a great tasting Smoked beer.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2008 Really interesting.  Has not only a great porter base but add the great smokey flavoring and you have something damn  good. Awesome flavor with a slight appley aftertaste that really sits nicely... GREAT

Poured from a 12 oz.  Dark chocolate color with brandy glow around the edges.  Milk, cocoa, and lightly cooked bacon aroma; bonfire, and a hint of cold-press french roast, though its acridity is restrained and playing comfortably into the larger context of thick sweetness.  Flavor suggests lactose sugar, honey, berries, and heavy dark malts; mild astringency.  Acerbic, brash cola and licorice sweetness, smoke being less prevalent than vanilla and sarsaparilla tones.  Lemon touch.  Palate is somewhat too light, with a slight sharpness; this tends to lend an inordinate strength to those cola tones.  Ashen coffee ground finish.  Enjoyable, certainly, but it would benefit greatly from a bit more weight.  Thanks for sharing, Ryan!

Smells just like a delicious piece of smoked sausage.  Wheres a cracker when you need it?  Im generally not a fan of smoked beers but this was noticeable enough, yet subtle enough not to make me gag.  Balanced, smokey, malty.

Pours a huge rocky head and looks downright mean in the glass.  Nice nose of woodsmoke.  Taste is smoky of course with lots of maltiness, cookies, chocolate as youd expect.  What makes this beer so nice is how perfectly balanced and smooth a quaff it is for such a fat beer.  As easy to drink as a Bamberg lager.  Very good effort, just not a huge, over-the-top thing that so many others seem to do these days and call it good.

12oz bottle, courtesy of artusory.  Thanks, Ryan!  Pours a dark, brownish-black color; khaki-colored head with fine bubbled lacing.  Pleasant barbecue and smoked meats in the aroma; spiciness and the smokiness of smoked gouda.  Medium-to-full, smoky mouthfeel: pleasant spiciness and chewy smoked meats, with a roasted and medium-bodied dark chocolatey porter underneath, well-integrated; lots of tasty smokiness while steering clear of inky liquid smoke character and keeping a fair amount of drinkability; the smoke itself is spicy and exceptional.  Lengthy, smoke and brown sugar and doughiness in the finish.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2007 Pours a dark a brown color with light brown head.  Aroma is of smoked meats, light chocolate and light blue cheese funkiness.  Taste is of smoked meats, chocolate, and some light malt.  I first thought the downfall of this beer was its thin finish, but after resampling this beer its quite solid.  I was really hoping that Dan would brew the Smoked Rye Bock again though.  Doh!

A bit effervescent, then the head dies to a really small sustained ring. Deep dark mahogany, smells of wood and a bit of bacon, caramel and pepper. Smoky and sweet, with a sourish meaty presence (umami) rolling around on the tongue. The sweet part is just a bit of brown sugar. A bit astringent in the flavor, and thats OK, but the thinness detracts a bit. Thanks Ughsmash!
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Bottled.  Poured clear, deep ruddy brown with a short cap of beige/light brown headage.  The aroma was quite delightful.. soft and calculated smoked meaty malts, well-roasted dark chocolate, other black malts, and brown sugar all blended together seamlessly.. I like how the smoke is a player, but doesnt mask the roasty dark malts.  The flavor had a dry-roasted, medium-bodied, chocolate and coffee-based porter at the core, with light coffee bitterness and the same sweeter smoked malts and woodiness surrounding (some smoked malts wash over the deeper-rooted chocolate and some darker fruity malts especially at the back-end)... sweet overall with nice roast and smoky accents.  Light-medium bodied and dry on the palate with lower carbonation.. well-balanced.. sweet, smoky finish.  This was mighty tasty!

12oz, no date, though I think it was bottled within the last week.  Deep deep ruby with a one finger tan head, fades to a creamy film.  Didnt have a hard time finding the smoke at all, though it isnt as smoky as Schlenkerla.  Roasted malts--not like coffee in this case--and some fruity notes (I cant put my finger on it) are up front.  Theres also some light spice and soft notes of brown sugar.  Flavor adds a little more smoke clear to the ashy, roasty dry finish (bitterness peaks at a 3).  Backing up a bit, flavor has plenty of roast with the acidic tang I pick up in most porters/stouts.  Also some milk chocolate notes.  Smooth low to moderate carbonation with a light to medium body--I echo that its just a tad thin.  Very good stuff!
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Pours a very dark brown/black with dark red when tilted to the light. Head is a light tan color that retains well and leaves some nice lacing. Smell is roasty, with some smokiness (though not much) and has hints of sweet cherries. Taste is roasty right at the start, leading into a little bit of sweetness from lactose followed by a lighter fruitiness (pear-like?) and of course has a lingering smoky finish. Mouthfeel is smooth with a medium body and on the lower side of carbonation. Good beer, Ill have to try it again in something other than a pint glass.

Dark color.  Smell of roasted coffee, malt, chocolate frosting, minor smoke, caramel and burning leaves.  Taste of malt, dark chocolate, light brown sugar, hops, roasted coffee and light smoke flavor.  Very smooth and goes down very nice.  Wonderful smoked porter.

Oakey,grain malt aromakissed by the delectable scent of Beechwood loved German malt,taste is a wonderful combination of coffees choclate fudge,and subtle roastedness,all tenderly laced with the hint of smoke leaving a slight coffee and smoke taste on the tongue,mouthfeel is light medium,and you start losing the smoke in the middle of the glass,its a really good porter from Mr. Carey,just a touch thin to be considered classic

Very dark brown color with a thin, stable lid of dark beige bubbles. Light aromas of smoke enveloped by dark chocolate, roasted malts and pale malts. A smooth subtle scent that just begs for a smoke sausage, grilled meats or a peasant feast. Very smooth and creamy feel. This feels like a perfect cask ale, smooth with a small bubbles gliding the liquid across the tongue. Starts out quite dry with roasted malts. Middle is full of dark caramel, full malt sweetness and a touch of herbal hops. Linger is solid with the full malt spectrum, from pale to roasted, with toasted in between. While I wouldnt mind a touch more smoke, this is another great brew from New Glarus.
